=== [[Talk:Donald Trump#rfc_3DFC1FB|Talk:Donald Trump]] expired 2021-01-15 16:01 ===
* Id: 3DFC1FB
* User: GUtt01
* Date: 2021-01-14 17:13:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Politics,_government,_and_law|prev|1000334203|POL 1000334203}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Politics,_government,_and_law|prev|1000549203|POL 1000549203}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
I have a serious question for this terminology's use, not just in this article, but also in any articles where it has been used to describe someone that was found guilty of crimes while the political leader of their country. When someone is facing impeachment, why must we say they were "impeached"? That term is for someone removed from their political office, I believe, not for someone who is facing impeachment. Should this terminology be reserved for those who were removed from office, not facing impeachment?

* '''YES''' - Political figures who were not removed from their office need this term replaced with something suitable and correct.
* '''NO''' - This term is suitable and fine, even if the political figure was not removed from their office.

[[User:GUtt01|GUtt01]] ([[User talk:GUtt01|talk]]) 17:13, 14 January 2021 (UTC)}}

=== [[Wikipedia:Reliable sources/Noticeboard#rfc_2E63085|Wikipedia:Reliable sources/Noticeboard]] expired 2021-01-16 04:01 ===

Which of the following best describes the [[WP:RS|reliability]] of ''[[Business Insider]]''? 

{{Domain uses|businessinsider.com}}<br/>
{{Domain uses|businessinsider.in}}<br/>
{{Domain uses|businessinsider.co.za}}<br/>
{{Domain uses|businessinsider.com.au}}

*'''Option 1:''' Generally [[WP:RS|reliable]] for factual reporting
*'''Option 2:''' Unclear or additional considerations apply
*'''Option 3:''' Generally [[WP:QUESTIONABLE|unreliable]] for factual reporting
*'''Option 4:''' Publishes false or fabricated information, and should be [[WP:DEPS|deprecated]] as in the [[Wikipedia:Reliable_sources/Noticeboard/Archive_220#Daily_Mail_RfC|2017 RfC]] of the ''[[Daily Mail]]''?

=== [[Talk:Basis (linear algebra)#rfc_FCD3F07|Talk:Basis (linear algebra)]] expired 2021-01-16 09:01 ===
* Id: FCD3F07
* User: AP295
* Date: 2021-01-16 00:22:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Maths,_science,_and_technology|prev|1000651276|SCI 1000651276}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Maths,_science,_and_technology|prev|1006014174|SCI 1006014174}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
[[Sequences]] are a more natural object with which to define the term "basis" than sets, and I'd like to edit the article accordingly. 
 
Since sequences are ordered collections, it would obviate the need for phrases like "ordered basis", which frequently appear in the article. Using sequence notation also makes things much simpler notation-wise, and better lends itself to inductive arguments and other constructions on paper. For example, if you have two bases as sequences (a1,a2,a3) and (b1,b2,b3) of two orthogonal subspaces of R^6, then (a1,a2,a3,b1,b2,b3) is a basis for R^6, and the order is unambiguous despite not being implied by the subscripts alone. As another example, in concatenating (a1,a2,a3) and (a1), the obtained sequence (a1,a2,a3,a1) is not a basis and we can simply say "the sequence is not a basis". However, the union of the sets {a1,a2,a3}, {a1} would be a basis, and we'd have to say something like awkward like "the elements of {a1,a2,a3} and {a1} are not a linearly independent collection of vectors". Is there anything to be gained by calling them sets? The two books I have on linear algebra, Linear Algebra Done Right by Axler, and Linear Algebra by Shilov, use sequences or sequence-like notation. I'm having a similar conversation on the [[Change of basis]] talk page, but I see that they're called sets in this article too. [[User:AP295|AP295]] ([[User talk:AP295|talk]]) 00:22, 16 January 2021 (UTC)}}

=== [[Talk:Basis (linear algebra)#rfc_B2F0217|Talk:Basis (linear algebra)]] expired 2021-01-16 20:01 ===
* Id: B2F0217
* User: AP295
* Date: 2021-01-16 00:22:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Maths,_science,_and_technology|prev|1000791465|SCI 1000791465}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Maths,_science,_and_technology|prev|1000802014|SCI 1000802014}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
[[Sequences]] are a more natural object with which to define the term "basis" than sets, and I'd like to edit the article accordingly. 
 
Since sequences are ordered collections, it would obviate the need for phrases like "ordered basis", which frequently appear in the article. Using sequence notation also makes things much simpler notation-wise, and better lends itself to inductive arguments and other constructions on paper. For example, if you have two bases as sequences (a1,a2,a3) and (b1,b2,b3) of two orthogonal subspaces of R^6, then (a1,a2,a3,b1,b2,b3) is a basis for R^6, and the order is unambiguous despite not being implied by the subscripts alone. As another example, in concatenating (a1,a2,a3) and (a1), the obtained sequence (a1,a2,a3,a1) is not a basis and we can simply say "the sequence is not a basis". However, the union of the sets {a1,a2,a3}, {a1} would be a basis, and we'd have to say something like awkward like "the elements of {a1,a2,a3} and {a1} are not a linearly independent collection of vectors". Is there anything to be gained by calling them sets? The two books I have on linear algebra, Linear Algebra Done Right by Axler, and Linear Algebra by Shilov, use sequences or sequence-like notation. I'm having a similar conversation on the [[Change of basis]] talk page, but I see that they're called sets in this article too. [[User:AP295|AP295]] ([[User talk:AP295|talk]]) 00:22, 16 January 2021 (UTC)}}

* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
Do these reverted additions to the article's three sections conflict or conform with Wikipedia Policies & guidelines,(more specifically, the citations [[WP:RS]] status) and do they make the article better or worse? Especially regarding to [[WP:NPOV]] "presenting fairly, proportionately, and, as far as possible, without editorial bias, all the significant views that have been published by reliable sources on a topic"[[User:Bigbaby23|Bigbaby23]] ([[User talk:Bigbaby23|talk]]) 21:35, 10 January 2021 (UTC)}}

=== [[Talk:Jon Ossoff#rfc_1E55A80|Talk:Jon Ossoff]] expired 2021-01-19 20:01 ===
* Id: 1E55A80
* User: Bigpoliticsfan
* Date: 2021-01-16 20:26:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Biographies|prev|1001394093|BIO 1001394093}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
Regarding the recent edit changing the reason for Ossoff being senior to Warnock from alphabetical by last name to full term/unexpired term citing the House Rules Committee's website as the source, I could find nothing on either the House Rules Committee's website or Senate Rules Committee's website to support that. On top of that, even though something has been found on a US House website in support of that claim, that is not how the American system of government works because that is not how the British system of government works. In the British system of government, on which the American system of government is modeled, the rules of each chamber of the legislature are binding only on that chamber. Therefore even though the cited source for full term/unexpired term rather than alphabetical by last name is "labeled" CRS (Congressional Research Service), it CANNOT be used for articles relating to the US Senate and the edit that stated thusly MUST be changed back under [[Wikipedia:V]], [[Wikipedia:NPOV]], and [[Wikipedia:NOR]] --[[User:Bigpoliticsfan|Bigpoliticsfan]] ([[User talk:Bigpoliticsfan|talk]]) 20:26, 16 January 2021 (UTC)}}

=== [[Talk:Ivermectin#rfc_92EB3A8|Talk:Ivermectin]] expired 2021-01-20 17:01 ===

* User: Vrtlsclpl

{{rfcquote|text=
On January 14, 2021, the NIH changed their recommendation on the use of Ivermectin in COVID-19. [https://www.covid19treatmentguidelines.nih.gov/statement-on-ivermectin/ The updated recommendation] states "...currently there are insufficient data to recommend either for or against the use of ivermectin for the treatment of COVID-19."   This recommendation is now the same as for the widely used monoclonal antibodies & convalescent plasma.  Is it appropriate to add a section entitled Medical_uses#COVID-19 ?--[[User:Vrtlsclpl|Vrtlsclpl]] ([[User talk:Vrtlsclpl|talk]]) 16:47, 15 January 2021 (UTC)}}

=== [[Talk:Conservative Party (UK)#rfc_F1358A0|Talk:Conservative Party (UK)]] expired 2021-01-21 18:01 ===
* Id: F1358A0
* User: Crunchynotsmooth
* Date: 2021-01-20 13:14:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Politics,_government,_and_law|prev|1001614416|POL 1001614416}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Politics,_government,_and_law|prev|1001852679|POL 1001852679}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
My edit to Conservative Party (UK) has been reverted by [[user:Czello|Czello]] on the basis there is 'no consensus', as have several previous attempts to make such a change. The edit in question is changing the description of party's position on the political spectrum from 'centre-right' to 'centre-right to right-wing' to include the broad range of factions in the party. Please refer to the discussions and arguments on this talk page for context. 

Additionally, from looking at similar pages which have been the subject of similar disputes, such as [[Conservative Party of Canada]], it can be seen that there is precedent for such an approach.

This debate has dragged out over several years on the [[talk:Conservative Party (UK)|talk page]] and I‚Äôve noticed have noticed Czello has recently engaged in edit warring over this, so I thought it best to seek RfC as soon as possible. 

It should be noted that there is by no means unanimous agreement for / against this change, but from looking at the [[talk:Conservative Party (UK)|talk]] page, there are more contributors favouring such a change. Moreover, [[user:BDD|BDD]] (incumbent on the arbitration committee) has stated ‚ÄúI think it's reasonable to say there's consensus on the talk page for such a change‚Äù, although this a non-binding judgement. 

Any help would be appreciated ASAP.

Many thanks [[User:Crunchynotsmooth|Crunchynotsmooth]] ([[User talk:Crunchynotsmooth|talk]]) 13:14, 20 January 2021 (UTC)}}

=== [[Talk:2021 storming of the United States Capitol#rfc_584AC31|Talk:2021 storming of the United States Capitol]] expired 2021-01-24 20:01 ===
* Id: 584AC31
* User: Casprings
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/History_and_geography|prev|1002451941|HIST 1002451941}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Media,_the_arts,_and_architecture|prev|1002451947|MEDIA 1002451947}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Politics,_government,_and_law|prev|1002451957|POL 1002451957}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Society,_sports,_and_culture|prev|1002451962|SOC 1002451962}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/History_and_geography|prev|1002597671|HIST 1002597671}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Media,_the_arts,_and_architecture|prev|1002597676|MEDIA 1002597676}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Politics,_government,_and_law|prev|1002597688|POL 1002597688}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Society,_sports,_and_culture|prev|1002597693|SOC 1002597693}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=This RFC is meant to gain consensus for a follow-on [[Wikipedia:RM]]. The current title was, [[Talk:2021 storming of the United States Capitol/Archive 2#Requested move 6 January 2021|per the closer]], a temporary solution. Current discussion and a currently [[Talk:2021 storming of the United States Capitol#Requested move 23 January 2021|open move request]] concerns the use of riot, attack, or storming. I would ask that you vote on the following choices and, if you favor two or more, to '''rank''' your votes.  

* '''Choice A''' Use the term '''attack''', as in the title '''2021 United States Capitol attack'''
* '''Choice B''' Use the term '''riot''', as in the title '''2021 United States Capitol riot'''
* '''Choice C''' Use the term '''storming''', as in the current title. 

Second, a '''yes''' or '''no''' question:

* '''Yes''' or '''no''' Does the title need the year to meet [[Wikipedia:Article titles|WP:TITLE]].[[User:Casprings|Casprings]] ([[User talk:Casprings|talk]]) 19:29, 24 January 2021 (UTC)
}}

=== [[Talk:PragerU#rfc_C24B0B6|Talk:PragerU]] expired 2021-01-24 23:01 ===
* Id: C24B0B6
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/History_and_geography|prev|1002531232|HIST 1002531232}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Society,_sports,_and_culture|prev|1002531239|SOC 1002531239}}

** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Society,_sports,_and_culture|prev|1008551743|SOC 1008551743}}
* RFC Text:

<!-- [[User:DoNotArchiveUntil]] 22:01, 28 February 2021 (UTC) -->{{User:ClueBot III/DoNotArchiveUntil|1614549685}}

Each of the proposed additions is described, and is then followed by a Survey section.  Answer Yes in each of the Survey sections to include the material or No to exclude the material.  Be brief and concise in the Survey, and do not respond to other editors.  A Threaded Discussion section is provided for discussion following each item, in which the most important rule is [[WP:CIVIL|civility]].

=== [[Talk:List of Asian Americans and Pacific Islands Americans in the United States Congress#rfc_25078CA|Talk:List of Asian Americans and Pacific Islands Americans in the United States Congress]] expired 2021-01-25 05:01 ===
* Id: 25078CA
* User: Nevermore27
* Date: 2020-12-26 04:05:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Politics,_government,_and_law|prev|996371880|POL 996371880}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Politics,_government,_and_law|prev|1002597688|POL 1002597688}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
It seems like the major focus of this [[WP:EDITWAR]] is where to put the notes marking historical firsts. Since this article covers multiple ethnicities rather than another more singular characteristic (like African-American or sexual orientation), some have the view that putting in the Notes column is cumbersome and prefer to put them in a reference. I disagree, I think having them readily visible in the table itself is preferable. So the question is this: '''Table''' or '''Reference'''? '''[[User:Nevermore27|<span style="color: #660198">Nevermore27</span>]]''' ([[User talk:Nevermore27|talk]]) 04:05, 26 December 2020 (UTC)}}

=== [[Wikipedia talk:Article titles#rfc_C0C6D1B|Wikipedia talk:Article titles]] expired 2021-01-27 01:01 ===
* Id: C0C6D1B
* User: Stevie fae Scotland
* Date: 2020-12-27 23:38:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Media,_the_arts,_and_architecture|prev|996665852|MEDIA 996665852}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Society,_sports,_and_culture|prev|996665857|SOC 996665857}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_style_and_naming|prev|996665861|STYLE 996665861}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_policies_and_guidelines|prev|996665866|POLICY 996665866}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Media,_the_arts,_and_architecture|prev|1003002620|MEDIA 1003002620}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Society,_sports,_and_culture|prev|1003002627|SOC 1003002627}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_style_and_naming|prev|1003002634|STYLE 1003002634}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_policies_and_guidelines|prev|1003002642|POLICY 1003002642}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
Following on from a proposed page move at [[Talk:Olympic Stadium (Amsterdam)#Requested move 10 December 2020]], I am seeking to include a specific naming convention for articles on sports stadia. Apart from [[WP:CHURCH]], which is an essay rather than a formal policy, there aren't any specific naming conventions for buildings and structures and I had understood that [[WP:NCPLACE]] applied to sports stadia in that: {{tq|Generic parenthetical disambiguating tags as used for most Wikipedia articles are used only occasionally for geographic names}}. As buildings and structures are located in named places rather than instances of the named place, I believe that this convention should also apply to sports stadia whereby the primary disambiguator should be the city or town they are located unless there is a more suitable disambiguator, for example [[Wembley Stadium]] and [[Wembley Stadium (1923)]]. I would like to know other editors opinions on avoiding the use of parenthetical disambiguating tags for sports stadia as well as the most appropriate project page for including a new naming convention for sports stadia as I am unsure whether [[WP:NCPLACE]] is the correct place to include a new naming convention for sports stadia as a result of the requested move discussion above. [[User:Stevie fae Scotland|Stevie fae Scotland]] ([[User talk:Stevie fae Scotland|talk]]) 23:38, 27 December 2020 (UTC)}}

=== [[Wikipedia talk:WikiProject Ukraine#rfc_ED5A9E4|Wikipedia talk:WikiProject Ukraine]] expired 2021-01-27 22:01 ===
* Id: ED5A9E4
* User: Ymblanter
* Date: 2020-12-28 21:36:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/History_and_geography|prev|996978085|HIST 996978085}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_style_and_naming|prev|996978090|STYLE 996978090}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/History_and_geography|prev|1003201840|HIST 1003201840}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_style_and_naming|prev|1003201857|STYLE 1003201857}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
Now, we need to agree how we call different type of amalhamated hromadas, which in Ukrainian are –º—ñ—Å—å–∫–∞ –≥—Ä–æ–º–∞–¥–∞, —Å–µ–ª–∏—â–Ω–∞ –≥—Ä–æ–º–∞–¥–∞, and —Å—ñ–ª—å—Å—å–∫–∞ –≥—Ä–æ–º–∞–¥–∞. One option would be to call them city hromada, settlement hroada, and village hromada. The drawbacks are that this is not English, and in some cases might be misleading (for example, a rural settlement which is not a village can be the seat of a village hromada). Another option, which I so far was using, is to use urban hromada and rural hrtomada. This is much better English, but this classification does not discriminate between –º—ñ—Å—å–∫–∞ –≥—Ä–æ–º–∞–¥–∞ and —Å–µ–ª–∏—â–Ω–∞ –≥—Ä–æ–º–∞–¥–∞. My preference is the second one, but we need to discuss the terms before I add so many of them that correction would become impractical. So far I already have added them in several hundred articles.--[[User:Ymblanter|Ymblanter]] ([[User talk:Ymblanter|talk]]) 21:36, 28 December 2020 (UTC)}}

=== [[Talk:American Basketball Association (2000‚Äìpresent)#rfc_05A823A|Talk:American Basketball Association (2000‚Äìpresent)]] expired 2021-01-27 22:01 ===
* Id: 05A823A
* User: LionMans Account
* Date: 2021-01-27 01:49:00

* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
Should we keep the team listings here?  They haven't been seriously updated for a few years now.  It looks like nobody really want to take care of it either.  Unlike most leagues, it is extremely difficult to get something relatively accurate here since teams come and go pretty quickly.  Teams are regularly announced then immediately disappear.  Aside from that, if we choose to keep it, how should team listings to be done?  Should we keep some standards or just use the random mess the ABA site has?

Personally, I would suggest removing the listing and suggest checking the ABA site if someone is actually interested.  [[User:LionMans Account|LionMans Account]] ([[User talk:LionMans Account|talk]]) 01:49, 27 January 2021 (UTC)}}

=== [[Talk:Godzilla vs. Kong#rfc_79CD4C9|Talk:Godzilla vs. Kong]] expired 2021-01-29 18:01 ===
* Id: 79CD4C9
* User: WhoKnew99
* Date: 2021-01-28 09:45:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Media,_the_arts,_and_architecture|prev|1003301350|MEDIA 1003301350}}

* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
Request for comments to change the plot synopsis/premise to the official one used by Warner Bros. and Legendary Entertainment for Godzilla vs. Kong. 

Official synopsis:

"Legends collide in ‚ÄúGodzilla vs. Kong‚Äù as these mythic adversaries meet in a spectacular battle for the ages, with the fate of the world hanging in the balance. Kong and his protectors undertake a perilous journey to find his true home, and with them is Jia, a young orphaned girl with whom he has formed a unique and powerful bond. But they unexpectedly find themselves in the path of an enraged Godzilla, cutting a swath of destruction across the globe. The epic clash between the two titans‚Äîinstigated by unseen forces‚Äîis only the beginning of the mystery that lies deep within the core of the Earth." [https://www.warnerbros.com/movies/godzilla-vs-kong#about] [https://www.godzillavskong.net/?synopsis]

Outdated synopsis no longer used by Warner Bros. or Legendary:

In a time when monsters walk the Earth, humanity's fight for its future sets Godzilla and Kong on a collision course that will see the two most powerful forces of nature on the planet collide in a spectacular battle for the ages. As Monarch embarks on a perilous mission into uncharted terrain and unearths clues to the Titans' origins, a human conspiracy threatens to wipe the creatures, both good and bad, from the face of the earth forever.

[[User:WhoKnew99|WhoKnew99]] ([[User talk:WhoKnew99|talk]]) 09:45, 28 January 2021 (UTC)}}

=== [[Wikipedia:Reliable sources/Noticeboard#rfc_A256D49|Wikipedia:Reliable sources/Noticeboard]] expired 2021-01-30 09:01 ===
* Id: A256D49
* Date: 2021-01-11 15:10:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Politics,_government,_and_law|prev|999715129|POL 999715129}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_proposals|prev|999715142|PROP 999715142}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Politics,_government,_and_law|prev|1003710897|POL 1003710897}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_proposals|prev|1003710899|PROP 1003710899}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
Should [[SCOTUSblog]] be considered a reliable source for law-related articles? Previous discussions for context: [[Wikipedia:Reliable sources/Noticeboard/Archive 38#Tom Goldstein and SCOTUSblog as sources for Supreme Court articles|Archive 38]] and [[Wikipedia:Reliable sources/Noticeboard/Archive 301#Determining whether a source is SPS in deciding whether BLPSPS applies|Archive 301]]. 15:10, 11 January 2021 (UTC)}}

=== [[Talk:List of people from Ukraine#rfc_F044064|Talk:List of people from Ukraine]] expired 2021-01-31 11:01 ===
* Id: F044064
* User: Ymblanter
* Date: 2021-01-01 10:06:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Biographies|prev|997607745|BIO 997607745}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/History_and_geography|prev|997607748|HIST 997607748}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Biographies|prev|1003932530|BIO 1003932530}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/History_and_geography|prev|1003932533|HIST 1003932533}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
Here we go again. [[User:Artixxxl|Artixxxl]] is adding to the list people who are not Ukrainian citizens, who were not born in Ukraine (or area which is now Ukraine) and never lived there, on the nasis that they have Ukrainian ancestry (one example of [[Alexei Navalny]] spending summers with his grandparents - which I personally find completely ridiculous; in this way everybody who was on holidays in Crimea between 1954 and 2014 - or even possibly after 2014 - can be added to the list) and this would make the list potentially of infinite size - even I would qualify for inclison. Therefore we need to define the scope very clearly. Below I list categories of notable individuals, please argue whether these need to be included.--[[User:Ymblanter|Ymblanter]] ([[User talk:Ymblanter|talk]]) 10:06, 1 January 2021 (UTC)}}

=== [[Wikipedia:Village pump (proposals)#rfc_6D41195|Wikipedia:Village pump (proposals)]] expired 2021-01-31 23:01 ===
* Id: 6D41195
* User: Elliot321
* Date: 2021-01-15 20:25:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_technical_issues_and_templates|prev|1000781363|TECH 1000781363}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_proposals|prev|1000781370|PROP 1000781370}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_technical_issues_and_templates|prev|1006666277|TECH 1006666277}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_proposals|prev|1006666292|PROP 1006666292}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
The Gadget and Gadget Definition namespaces are unused, have never been used, and have confusing documentation at [[Wikipedia:Gadget]] due to having never been used. Apparently, all relevant gadgets are in MediaWiki-space (for example, [[MediaWiki:Gadget-Twinkle.js]]). Considering this, there is no reason to keep the namespaces around. 

Somewhat relevant: 
* [https://phabricator.wikimedia.org/tag/gadgets-2.0/ Phab tasks for Gadgets-2.0, which would supposedly use this namespace]
* [[Wikipedia:Village_pump_(technical)/Archive_139#New_"Gadget:"_and_"Gadget_definition:"_namespaces?|Previous post at the technical village pump about Gadgetspace]]

If after five years nothing has happened, I doubt anything will happen with the namespace in the future. [[User:Elliot321|Elliot321]] ([[User_talk:Elliot321|talk]] &#124; [[Special:Contributions/Elliot321|contribs]]) 20:25, 15 January 2021 (UTC)}}

=== [[Talk:Variant of Concern 202012/01#rfc_84ABC44|Talk:Variant of Concern 202012/01]] expired 2021-02-03 09:01 ===
* Id: 84ABC44
* User: JackFromReedsburg
* Date: 2021-01-05 15:55:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Maths,_science,_and_technology|prev|998483189|SCI 998483189}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Maths,_science,_and_technology|prev|1004579959|SCI 1004579959}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
Should the article include the terms ''UK Coronavirus variant'', ''UK COVID-19 variant'', or related "UK" names? (Sources are listed in [[Talk:U.K. Coronavirus variant]] and [[Talk:U.K. Covid-19 variant]])
* '''Option A''' - Include
**'''A1''': in article's lead
**'''A2''': in Nomenclature's opening sentence
**'''A3''': brush it off at the end of Nomenclature
* '''Option B''' - Don't include
* '''Option C''' - Mention that the strain was initially called "''UK COVID-19 strain''", in a similar way to [[COVID-19#Name]]
Thanks, '''''[[User:JackFromReedsburg|JackFromReedsburg]]''''' ([[User_talk:JackFromReedsburg|talk]] &#124; [[Special:Contributions/JackFromReedsburg|contribs]]) 15:55, 5 January 2021 (UTC)}}

=== [[Talk:List of wars and anthropogenic disasters by death toll#rfc_ED993EC|Talk:List of wars and anthropogenic disasters by death toll]] expired 2021-02-06 06:01 ===
* Id: ED993EC
* User: C.J. Griffin
* Date: 2021-02-05 15:14:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/History_and_geography|prev|1005061378|HIST 1005061378}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/History_and_geography|prev|1005149186|HIST 1005149186}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
I would like assistance to know why this new scholarly peer reviewed source https://digitalcommons.liberty.edu/cgi/viewcontent.cgi?article=1350&context=honors is not being accepted now? I would also like assistance on how my addition of Mass Killings Under Communist Regimes is not being allowed if the European colonization with 1 source has been allowed?

:Sources like the ''Reason'' and op-eds in online newspapers are not reliable sources in the least. The issue of "[[Mass killings under communist regimes]]" is highly controversial anyway with disputes on that talk page going on as I type this, so it is not necessary to shoehorn such a controversial and contested topic into this article using such rubbish sources. It seems your edits on the aforementioned article [https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Mass_killings_under_communist_regimes&type=revision&diff=1004950265&oldid=1004939880 have been reverted anyway], and for similar reasons, so now you are bringing the same source and others here. Rummel is hardly a reliable source on deaths under communism, especially his estimates on the USSR which are not taken seriously by any historian on the subject. It is certainly ''not'' an "extremely reputable source everyone uses." And just because you have issues with another part of the article on European colonization doesn't justify your edits which have been rightly reverted on the Mass killings under communist regimes article.--[[User:C.J. Griffin|C.J. Griffin]] ([[User talk:C.J. Griffin|talk]]) 15:14, 5 February 2021 (UTC)}}

=== [[Talk:Ariana Grande#rfc_FDB2BF2|Talk:Ariana Grande]] expired 2021-02-09 13:01 ===
* Id: FDB2BF2
* User: Doggy54321
* Date: 2021-01-19 19:57:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Media,_the_arts,_and_architecture|prev|1001462980|MEDIA 1001462980}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Media,_the_arts,_and_architecture|prev|1005795238|MEDIA 1005795238}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
There has been an ongoing debate between editors since October 2020, and probably even before then. The debate is about if [[Ariana Grande]] should be listed as a songwriter. Generally, editors who support this idea cite that she has written almost all of her songs since her debut album [[Yours Truly (Ariana Grande album)|''Yours Truly'']] (2013),  while editors who oppose this idea cite that no sources have been given establishing/proving Grande's notability as a songwriter. I have decided to start an RfC as consensus isn‚Äôt forming yet. Please keep comments short, staying on topic, and be mindful of Wikipedia policies such as [[WP:SYNTH|the synthesis of material policy]], [[WP:BLP|the biographies of living persons policy]], [[WP:NOR|the no original research policy]] and [[WP:NPOV|the neutral point-of-view policy]]. Thank you! <span class="nowrap">[[User:Doggy54321|Düê∂ggy54321]]</span> <span class="nowrap"><sup>([[User talk:Doggy54321|let's chat!]])</sup></span> 19:57, 19 January 2021 (UTC)}}

Need consensus on how to keep the naming style of a section: [https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?diff=1003209303&oldid=1003209117&title=Kong:_Skull_Island option A - Sequels] or [https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?diff=1003418163&oldid=1003417889&title=Kong:_Skull_Island option B - Sequel and anime series]. === [[Talk:Schlage doch, gew√ºnschte Stunde, BWV 53#rfc_90B9B27|Talk:Schlage doch, gew√ºnschte Stunde, BWV 53]] expired 2021-02-10 16:01 ===

=== [[Talk:Schlage doch, gew√ºnschte Stunde, BWV 53#rfc_F10E9AE|Talk:Schlage doch, gew√ºnschte Stunde, BWV 53]] expired 2021-02-10 16:01 ===
* Id: F10E9AE
* Date: 2021-01-11 15:43:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_style_and_naming|prev|999715134|STYLE 999715134}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_style_and_naming|prev|1006014185|STYLE 1006014185}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
Per [[WP:CITEVAR]] consensus is needed to change a referencing system of an established article. The established referencing system for this article is without {{tl|sfn}} templates; a series of recent updates used these templates, with a separate list of sources, listed alphabetically by author ([https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Schlage_doch,_gew%C3%BCnschte_Stunde,_BWV_53&oldid=999711657]). Possibilities include converting newly introduced references to the formerly established system, and accepting {{tl|sfn}} with separate sources list as a viable referencing style. This RfC is not about content, nor about the article structure (after the recent updates better in line with [[Wikipedia:WikiProject Classical music/Guidelines#Structure]]), but exclusively about the article's referencing style. 15:43, 11 January 2021 (UTC)}}

=== [[Wikipedia talk:Featured articles#rfc_5688BA7|Wikipedia talk:Featured articles]] expired 2021-02-10 16:01 ===
* Id: 5688BA7
* User: AP295
* Date: 2021-02-09 17:51:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_proposals|prev|1005840996|PROP 1005840996}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_proposals|prev|1006014195|PROP 1006014195}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
STEM articles are extremely underrepresented in [[WP:FA]], and of the few that do exist, many are about products or services. I propose a review of high-importance articles in STEM to determine exactly what must be done in order for them to meet the featured article criteria, make appropriate edits, and award them featured article status as soon as possible, without delay. [[User:AP295|AP295]] ([[User talk:AP295|talk]]) 17:51, 9 February 2021 (UTC)}}

In the Spring of 2020, the [[Wikipedia:Notability#Subject-specific_notability_guidelines|current "Subject-specific notability guidelines" (SNG) section]] was added to [[WP:Notability]]. There has been [[Wikipedia_talk:Notability#SNG_change|extensive discussion]] on whether it should be kept, deleted or modified and, if modified, in what way.  The result was to propose the following RFC. 17:09, 11 January 2021 (UTC)}}

* Id: CAF1604
* User: Veverve
* Date: 2021-02-12 18:53:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Religion_and_philosophy|prev|1006408953|RELI 1006408953}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_technical_issues_and_templates|prev|1006408959|TECH 1006408959}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Religion_and_philosophy|prev|1006436726|RELI 1006436726}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_technical_issues_and_templates|prev|1006436734|TECH 1006436734}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
[[:Template:WikiProject Christianity]] currently shows "This article is supported by Canon law task force" and displays "/Canon Law" next to "WikiProject Christianity" if the parameter <code>catholic-canon-law</code> is set to <code>yes</code>. The hyperlinks send to [[Wikipedia:WikiProject Catholicism/Canon law Task Force]]. Therefore, since it only concerns [[:Catholic canon law]], I believe it should rather read "Catholic canon law task force" and display "/Catholic Canon Law". [[User:Veverve|Veverve]] ([[User talk:Veverve|talk]]) 18:53, 12 February 2021 (UTC)}}

* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
This is a two part [[WP:RFC|RfC]].

#Would it be helpful to internally link the pluralisation within the first sentence to the 'Etymology and pluralisation' header?
#*Example: "The '''octopus''' ([[Octopus#Etymology_and_pluralisation|plural '''octopuses''']]) is a soft-bodied..."
#*Reasoning: The correct pluralisation of 'octopus' is a fairly controversial topic, and linking the very first occurrence of it in the article to the section explaining pluralisation could help clear up any confusion. 
#Is [[Merriam-Webster]] a valid source on this topic, as I'm seeing the [[Oxford English Dictionary|Oxford dictionary]] being the primary dictionary source throughout this article instead?
#*Specifically, the article "[https://www.merriam-webster.com/words-at-play/the-many-plurals-of-octopus-octopi-octopuses-octopodes The Many Plurals of 'Octopus']" has some very good information that should be included and cited.
#*Currently, there are six separate sources from the Oxford dictionary, whereas there is only one from Merriam-Webster, and it's a [[WP:DEADLINK|dead link]].
- [[User:Dynamiccookies|Dynamiccookies]] ([[User talk:Dynamiccookies|talk]]) 18:09, 27 January 2021 (UTC)}}

=== [[Wikipedia talk:WikiProject Elections and Referendums#rfc_8AEACD4|Wikipedia talk:WikiProject Elections and Referendums]] expired 2021-02-20 00:01 ===
* Id: 8AEACD4
* User: Glide08
* Date: 2021-01-20 23:07:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Politics,_government,_and_law|prev|1001714015|POL 1001714015}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Politics,_government,_and_law|prev|1007797035|POL 1007797035}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
The consensus on Wikipedia for two-round election has traditionally been to only include the two candidates who made it to the second round. However, recent articles, such as [[2017 French presidential election]] and [[2020-21 United States Senate special election in Georgia]], display both the first and second round results in their infoboxes, and sometimes include candidates who did not make it to the second round. I believe this means a new consensus (not necessarily a change in policy) should be reached on the topic (especially given the high profile of the Georgia special senate election, which so far has not been altered to fit the old consensus).

My question is:

:Should election infoboxes for two-round elections:
:# show only the two candidates who advanced to the second round, and only the number of votes recieved in the second round?
:# show only the two candidates who advanced to the second round, and the numbers of votes recieved in both rounds?
:# or show the two candidates who advanced to the second round and any other canddiates who received 5% or more in the first round, and the numbers of votes recieved in both rounds?

[[User:Glide08|Glide08]] ([[User talk:Glide08|talk]]) 23:07, 20 January 2021 (UTC)}}

=== [[Wikipedia talk:WikiProject Years#rfc_FC87858|Wikipedia talk:WikiProject Years]] expired 2021-02-20 02:01 ===
* Id: FC87858
* User: Elizium23#References on date articles]] and [[Wikipedia:Reliable sources/Noticeboard/Archive 324#Year and date articles - sourcing]] there has been some controversy about [[WP:DOYCITE]], i.e. the new policy that "year" and "days of year" and "date" articles must conform to [[WP:V]] and have inline citations for entries. Therefore, {{u
* Date: 2021-01-21 01:06:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/History_and_geography|prev|1001732726|HIST 1001732726}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_policies_and_guidelines|prev|1001732736|POLICY 1001732736}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/History_and_geography|prev|1007814342|HIST 1007814342}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_policies_and_guidelines|prev|1007814345|POLICY 1007814345}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
Per [[User talk:Elizium23#References on date articles]] and [[Wikipedia:Reliable sources/Noticeboard/Archive 324#Year and date articles - sourcing]] there has been some controversy about [[WP:DOYCITE]], i.e. the new policy that "year" and "days of year" and "date" articles must conform to [[WP:V]] and have inline citations for entries. Therefore, {{u|Nihonjoe}} and {{u|Rcb1}} have variously proposed that we '''remove all unsourced content from the affected articles''' until it can be sourced, or like {{u|SomeBodyAnyBody05}}, that we not provide sources for any of it in the first place. So this RFC is simple: remove all uncited information from the affected articles? Yes/No? [[User:Elizium23|Elizium23]] ([[User talk:Elizium23|talk]]) 01:06, 21 January 2021 (UTC)}}

** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_proposals|prev|1005118598|PROP 1005118598}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Politics,_government,_and_law|prev|1005149189|POL 1005149189}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Media,_the_arts,_and_architecture|prev|1007830655|MEDIA 1007830655}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Politics,_government,_and_law|prev|1007830659|POL 1007830659}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_policies_and_guidelines|prev|1007830662|POLICY 1007830662}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_proposals|prev|1007830667|PROP 1007830667}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
Is [[Taiwan News]] a reliable source, a marginally reliable source, an unreliable source, or should it be deprecated? Does reliability still stand especially over political articles such as [[cross-strait relations]]?

According to Taiwan News, it is owned by [[I-Mei Foods]], and openly leans [[Pan-Green]] politically.

Website: [https://www.taiwannews.com.tw/en/index]

{{duses|taiwannews}} is currently cited on over 1,000 articles, and if I'm seeing correctly were all added in the last year or two.

*'''Option 1:''' Generally [[WP:RS|reliable]] for factual reporting, including politics.
*'''Option 2:''' Marginally reliable or unclear, considerations needed.
*'''Option 3:''' Generally [[WP:QUESTIONABLE|unreliable]] and too [[WP:PARTISAN|partisan]] for factual reporting.
*'''Option 4:''' Publishes false or fabricated information, and should be [[WP:DEPS|deprecated]].

Not sure if relevant: Taiwan News still largely refers to "COVID-19" as "Wuhan coronavirus", examples: [https://www.taiwannews.com.tw/en/news/4114965 1] and [https://www.taiwannews.com.tw/en/news/4120827 2]. Not sure if these are unintentional and are being meant casually/off-hand or is being used deliberately as a political statement. [[Special:Contributions/85.10.51.92|85.10.51.92]] ([[User talk:85.10.51.92|talk]]) 01:51, 6 February 2021 (UTC)}}

=== [[Wikipedia:Reliable sources/Noticeboard#rfc_7F8CE1E|Wikipedia:Reliable sources/Noticeboard]] expired 2021-02-20 04:01 ===
* Id: 7F8CE1E
* User: Adolphus79
* Date: 2021-02-03 23:55:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Politics,_government,_and_law|prev|1004710804|POL 1004710804}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_proposals|prev|1004710811|PROP 1004710811}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Politics,_government,_and_law|prev|1007830659|POL 1007830659}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_proposals|prev|1007830667|PROP 1007830667}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
[https://www.ourcampaigns.com/ This website] has been mentioned multiple times on this noticeboard over the last few years ([https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Special:Search?search=ourcampaigns&prefix=Wikipedia%3AReliable+sources%2FNoticeboard&fulltext=Search&fulltext=Search&ns0=1 see here]), but no RfC was ever generated or consensus reached regarding its reliability. The website is an open wiki, [[WP:SPS|fully user generated]], with no mention of from where the contributors are getting their numbers. There are currently [https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?search=ourcampaigns&title=Special%3ASearch&go=Go&ns0=1 over 3,000 instances] of it being cited as a source on Wikipedia (mostly on election related articles) that should be removed as a clear failure of [[WP:RS]].

Should the website be blacklisted/spamlisted to allow for mass-removal? - [[User:Adolphus79|Adolphus79]] ([[User talk:Adolphus79|talk]]) 23:55, 3 February 2021 (UTC)}}

=== [[Talk:Criticism of the Bah√°?√≠ Faith#rfc_2133A49|Talk:Criticism of the Bah√°?√≠ Faith]] expired 2021-02-23 17:01 ===
* Id: 2133A49
* User: Cu√±ado
* Date: 2021-02-05 17:57:00

* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
 How should the [[Bah√° º√≠ Faith]] be summarized in a sentence or two for the lead on [[Criticism of the Bah√° º√≠ Faith]]? 

Option 1: "The Bah√° º√≠ Faith is a new religious movement that originated in the 19th century and has around 5 million adherents. It grew initially in Iran out of Babism. It's religious foundations rest on many of the teachings of the Bab." 

Option 2: "The Bah√° º√≠ Faith is a relatively new world religion that originated in the 19th century and has around 5 million adherents. It grew initially in Iran out of Islamic influences but established its own laws and teachings that made a clear break from Islam."

Or an alternative. Both options have at least some support in reliable sources.

** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/History_and_geography|prev|1009631310|HIST 1009631310}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Politics,_government,_and_law|prev|1009631318|POL 1009631318}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
Since {{ping|Nillurcheier}} reverted my edits on making the lede from "is" to "was", I think that we should rewrite the first sentence of the lede since it is a country's historical era isn't it?

To coincide with [[North Vietnam]] and [[South Yemen]] which are divided nations during the Cold War, I think we should make it so that the first sentence is concise enough that it won't confuse readers because of the use of the present tense in the sentence. Any thoughts? [[User:PyroFloe|PyroFloe]] ([[User talk:PyroFloe|talk]]) 16:26, 22 February 2021 (UTC)}}

=== [[Talk:Turkish occupation of northern Syria#rfc_2C70744|Talk:Turkish occupation of northern Syria]] expired 2021-03-01 16:01 ===
* Id: 2C70744
* User: HakurSakur
* Date: 2021-02-24 12:05:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Politics,_government,_and_law|prev|1008667711|POL 1008667711}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Politics,_government,_and_law|prev|1009640439|POL 1009640439}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
 Turkey has had a number troops in Idlib since 2017. But since the Government offensive last year, Turkey has significantly increased its presence in the Idlib region (where Tahrir Al Sham is present). From 12 lightly armed and manned observation points with an estimate thousand troops. To between 20 to 30 thousand troops as of 2021 (according to US Special envoy for Syria[https://fresh-syria.net/archives/60107]). A number which is over the number of Turkish troops in the occupied Syrian territory excluding Idlib [[User:HakurSakur|HakurSakur]] ([[User talk:HakurSakur|talk]]) 12:05, 24 February 2021 (UTC)}}

=== [[Talk:Ben Garrison#rfc_6FFBD3F|Talk:Ben Garrison]] expired 2021-03-01 17:01 ===
* Id: 6FFBD3F
* User: BirdZilla
* Date: 2021-01-30 16:49:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Politics,_government,_and_law|prev|1003778051|POL 1003778051}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Politics,_government,_and_law|prev|1009650044|POL 1009650044}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
'''Rfc request:''' Following the discussion about using "far right", the description of the author has been changed to "alt-right" based on a small subset of sources. However, the majority of sources currently used by the article describe Garrison as either a "libertarian" or "pro-Trump" cartoonist whose work appeals to elements of the alt-right. Much of this is confounded by the fact that the artist's work has been repeatedly edited by third parties to imply support for positions which Garrison publicly rejects (see [https://www.wired.com/story/ben-garrison-alt-right-cartoonist/ this piece] as well as the [https://grrrgraphics.com/about/ author's website]). How should Garrison be described in the lead? - [[User:BirdZilla|BirdZilla]] ([[User talk:BirdZilla|talk]]) 16:49, 30 January 2021 (UTC)}}

=== [[Talk:Philosophy Tube#rfc_572F657|Talk:Philosophy Tube]] expired 2021-03-02 09:01 ===
* Id: 572F657
* Date: 2021-01-31 08:02:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Biographies|prev|1003917076|BIO 1003917076}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_style_and_naming|prev|1003917081|STYLE 1003917081}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_policies_and_guidelines|prev|1003917083|POLICY 1003917083}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Biographies|prev|1009789677|BIO 1009789677}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_style_and_naming|prev|1009789686|STYLE 1009789686}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_policies_and_guidelines|prev|1009789689|POLICY 1009789689}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
Since Saturday, January 30, 2021 (at 20:00:11 UTC to be exact) the creator of YouTube channel this article concerns, Thorn, announced publicly via YouTube and Twitter their [[transgender]] status, revealing their current first name, Abigail. Since this, it has become into editing dispute whether or not to include their former name, Oliver, which previously was throughout the article. EDIT: This name is different from the subject's birth name (Oliver Lennard), and the subject was not notable under their birth name, but was notable under the name "Oliver Thorn".

So the question at hand: '''Should Thorn's previous "dead" name "Oliver Thorn" be listed in the article?'''

*'''A''' ‚Äî Yes, Thorn's previous name should be '''included''' (in limited fashion allowed by guidelines).
*'''B''' ‚Äî No, Thorn's previous name should be '''omitted entirely'''.
*'''C''' ‚Äî Omit in the lead, include in early life. (proposed by {{u|Ceoil}}) (added 08:02, 31 January 2021 (UTC)}}

=== [[Wikipedia:Village pump (proposals)#rfc_5E26641|Wikipedia:Village pump (proposals)]] expired 2021-03-03 10:01 ===
* Id: 5E26641
* User: Theleekycauldron
* Date: 2021-03-01 23:35:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_proposals|prev|1009718600|PROP 1009718600}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_proposals|prev|1010003756|PROP 1010003756}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
Should we add pronouns to the signatures of new users? Should we add pronouns to the signatures of old users? What format should these pronouns be in, if they are added?

Options for new users:
:'''A''': Add new pronouns to signature automatically when they sign up, choosing their pronouns in the sign-up screen.
:'''B''': Give new users the option to add their pronouns to their signature when they sign up
:'''C''': Do nothing, do not give users the option to easily add their pronouns to their signature.

Options for already existing users:
:'''A''': A drive to encourage Wikipedians to add their pronouns to their signature in the way they choose
:'''B''': Automatically affixing the pronouns on file to the end of the signature
:'''C''': Not encouraging users to add pronouns to their signature

Options for format (using they/them as an example):
:'''A''': (They/Them)
:'''B''': (they/them)
:'''C''': <nowiki>[they/them]</nowiki>

[[User:Theleekycauldron|theleekycauldron]] ([[User talk:Theleekycauldron|talk]] ‚Ä¢ [[Special:Contributions/Theleekycauldron|contribs]]) ([[Singular they|they/them]]) 23:35, 1 March 2021 (UTC)}}

=== [[Talk:List of American liberals#rfc_D62E4D6|Talk:List of American liberals]] expired 2021-03-06 03:01 ===
* Id: D62E4D6
* User: Mottezen
* Date: 2021-02-04 02:15:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Politics,_government,_and_law|prev|1004736803|POL 1004736803}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Politics,_government,_and_law|prev|1010562770|POL 1010562770}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
What should be the selection criteria for inclusion on this list?

'''Option 1''' : Self-identification as a liberal ([[Talk:List_of_American_liberals#Criteria_Proposal|as articulated here]])

'''Option 2''' : Meeting the definition of a liberal ([https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=List_of_American_liberals&oldid=1003528283 as articulated in this now-deleted lead section])

'''Option 3''' : Other

'''Option 4''' : Strong consensus of multiple reliable sources that the person is a "liberal" (explicitly stated) in the sense of the US political definition of this era.

'''Option 5''' : Go with reliable sourcing, unless sources disagree (in which case disagreement is handled or covered according to which sources are strongest or best; when they're roughly even, include in the list with a note about the dispute.) A "strong consensus" is not required, merely description as a liberal in sources that pass [[WP:DUE]].

While important, the details of each linked proposal can be discussed in their respective sections above. The meat of the disagreement is the epistemology of inclusion. How do we know someone is a liberal? [[User:Mottezen|Mottezen]] ([[User talk:Mottezen|talk]]) 02:15, 4 February 2021 (UTC)}}

=== [[Talk:The Last Narc (TV series)#rfc_75EE319|Talk:The Last Narc (TV series)]] expired 2021-03-07 18:01 ===
* Id: 75EE319
* User: Darouet
* Date: 2021-02-05 17:06:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/History_and_geography|prev|1005041683|HIST 1005041683}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Media,_the_arts,_and_architecture|prev|1005041690|MEDIA 1005041690}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Politics,_government,_and_law|prev|1005041718|POL 1005041718}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/History_and_geography|prev|1010851640|HIST 1010851640}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Media,_the_arts,_and_architecture|prev|1010851652|MEDIA 1010851652}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Politics,_government,_and_law|prev|1010851657|POL 1010851657}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
Recent changes [https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=The_Last_Narc_%28TV_series%29&type=revision&diff=1004718778&oldid=1001734722] now describe the 2020 Amazon docuseries ''[[The Last Narc (TV series)]]'' as "fictional" in [[WP:WIKIVOICE]], mostly based on links to primary documents from the 1990s housed at http://www.reneverdugo.org. 

Furthermore, a one-paragraph "background" section has been proposed (see text here [https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=The_Last_Narc_%28TV_series%29&type=revision&diff=1004809631&oldid=1004753156]), using academic and newspaper sources that don't reference ''The Last Narc,'' but are on the same topic and present similar conclusions.

*'''Question 1''' ‚Äî should we describe the docuseries as "fictional" in Wikivoice, and should we cite http://www.reneverdugo.org as a source on this page?
*'''Question 2''' ‚Äî should we include this [https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=The_Last_Narc_%28TV_series%29&type=revision&diff=1005422420&oldid=1005372905] one-paragraph "background" section mentioned above?

Comments are appreciated. -[[User:Darouet|Darouet]] ([[User talk:Darouet|talk]]) 17:06, 5 February 2021 (UTC)}}

=== [[Talk:Crusading#rfc_6E302F3|Talk:Crusading]] expired 2021-03-08 21:01 ===
* Id: 6E302F3
* User: Norfolkbigfish
* Date: 2021-02-06 20:35:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/History_and_geography|prev|1005595448|HIST 1005595448}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/History_and_geography|prev|1011067308|HIST 1011067308}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
Can [[Crusading]] be used interchangeably with [[Crusades]] if used in a grammatically correct way{{mdash}}'''Yes''' or '''No'''?

For example, the opening sentence of the lead is ''Crusading was a series of [[religious wars]], sanctioned by the [[Latin Church]], that began in the [[Middle Ages]] and continued to be fought in several subsequent centuries.'' A GOCE review has passed the grammar, Wikidictionary defines ''Crusading'' as the present participle of ''Crusade'', no one would seriously deny the truth of the sentence and it is supported by multiple sources referring to the Crusades in the [[Crusading#Definition]] section.[[User:Norfolkbigfish|Norfolkbigfish]] ([[User talk:Norfolkbigfish|talk]]) 20:35, 6 February 2021 (UTC)}}

=== [[Wikipedia:Reliable sources/Noticeboard#rfc_1D2F262|Wikipedia:Reliable sources/Noticeboard]] expired 2021-03-10 04:01 ===
* Id: 1D2F262
* User: Dhawk790
* Date: 2021-02-15 00:25:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Media,_the_arts,_and_architecture|prev|1006905003|MEDIA 1006905003}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_proposals|prev|1006905008|PROP 1006905008}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Politics,_government,_and_law|prev|1007083131|POL 1007083131}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Media,_the_arts,_and_architecture|prev|1012152291|MEDIA 1012152291}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Politics,_government,_and_law|prev|1012152295|POL 1012152295}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_proposals|prev|1012152309|PROP 1012152309}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
Link: [https://www.rfa.org/english/]

Radio Free Asia (RFA) is a US government funded news source. They almost only publish news critical of enemies of the United States.  The articles regularly do not cite their sources, which makes their reporting unreliable. For example, this report (https://www.rfa.org/english/news/tibet/beatings-01222021193838.html) refers to "RFA‚Äôs source" and "Tibetan sources say." I think that RFA should be depreciated in line with a number of other state media sources.

Edit: Here is another example of an article that I would not consider entirely reliable: https://www.rfa.org/english/news/uyghur/cosleeping-10312019160528.html . Again it contains no named sources and it ended up being picked up by other media https://www.news.com.au/world/asia/this-is-mass-rape-china-slammed-over-program-that-appoints-men-to-sleep-with-uighur-women/news-story/ed45cd065e39690354b6402d02904557 . Just because it does not contain any named sources does not mean that it is fabricated, but I feel like, at least on a case by case basis, it might make sense to depreciate some articles from RFA that seem like they can't be authenticated. I don't know if there is any precedent for this.  

[[User:Dhawk790|Dhawk790]] ([[User talk:Dhawk790|talk]]) 00:25, 15 February 2021 (UTC)}}

=== [[Wikipedia talk:WikiProject Mathematics#rfc_53F148C|Wikipedia talk:WikiProject Mathematics]] expired 2021-03-11 21:01 ===
* Id: 53F148C
* User: AP295
* Date: 2021-02-09 20:11:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Maths,_science,_and_technology|prev|1006014174|SCI 1006014174}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Maths,_science,_and_technology|prev|1011609293|SCI 1011609293}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
STEM articles are extremely underrepresented in [[WP:FA]], and of the few that do exist, many are about products or services, biographical, or otherwise of a non-technical nature. I propose a review of top/high-importance articles in STEM to determine exactly what must be done in order for them to meet the featured article criteria, make appropriate edits, and award them featured article status as soon as possible, without delay. Particularly, material that is fundamental and important to scientific literacy in general or across multiple disciplines. I believe there must be a coordinated effort. Many scientific articles seem to become overly long and disjointed, with so many editors working independently. As a starting point, I think these three articles are all vital to basic scientific literacy and deserve very serious attention: [[Mean]], [[Function (mathematics)]], [[Set (mathematics)]]. My time is limited and I cannot improve them alone, but I would like to be part of such an effort. If at least a couple editors are interested, I'd like to set up an agenda, perhaps with a regular meeting. Once an article is agreed upon, we can read it, report back with comments, discuss how it can be raised to featured article status, and decide on specific edits.  [[User:AP295|AP295]] ([[User talk:AP295|talk]]) 20:11, 9 February 2021 (UTC)}}

=== [[Wikipedia:Village pump (proposals)#rfc_DA05E07|Wikipedia:Village pump (proposals)]] expired 2021-03-12 03:01 ===

'''Proposed:''' Effectively disable the "minor edits" functionality on the English Wikipedia. Its usage will be limited by policy for anti-vandalism reverts only. === [[Talk:List of presidents of the United States#rfc_762F548|Talk:List of presidents of the United States]] expired 2021-03-12 07:01 ===
* Id: 762F548
* User: Basil the Bat Lord
* Date: 2021-02-10 06:55:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Politics,_government,_and_law|prev|1005953664|POL 1005953664}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Politics,_government,_and_law|prev|1011683101|POL 1011683101}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
I opened a talk section about the Obama portrait but saw no discussion, so I'm opening an RfC.

All of the portraits listed on this page seem to follow the portraits listed on the official White House presidents list, which is most often the second-term portrait of Presidents who have served a second term (here: https://www.whitehouse.gov/about-the-white-house/presidents/)

Obama's portrait is an exception, his first-term portrait from 2009 is used in the article despite a second-term portrait existing and being used on the White House site and despite all of the presidents around him using their more recent portraits.

'''Question''': Which of these photos should be used for Barack Obama's portrait on this article?

* '''Option A''': First term portrait (current).
* '''Option B''': Second term portrait.
* '''Option C''': Cropped version of second term portrait. 

<gallery mode=packed heights=200px>
File:Official portrait of Barack Obama.jpg|Option A
File:President Barack Obama.jpg|Option B 
File: President Barack Obama (cropped) 4.jpg|Option C 
</gallery>

Personally I think Option C is suitable. [[User:Basil the Bat Lord|Basil the Bat Lord]] ([[User talk:Basil the Bat Lord|talk]]) 06:55, 10 February 2021 (UTC)}}

=== [[Talk:Terrance Yeakey#rfc_3EA7019|Talk:Terrance Yeakey]] expired 2021-03-12 18:01 ===
* Id: 3EA7019
* User: NedFausa
* Date: 2021-02-10 17:22:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Biographies|prev|1006034670|BIO 1006034670}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Politics,_government,_and_law|prev|1006034680|POL 1006034680}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Biographies|prev|1011762614|BIO 1011762614}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Politics,_government,_and_law|prev|1011762622|POL 1011762622}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
Does this biographical article overemphasize a fringe theory and rely excessively on sources that promote conspiracy theories? Our relevant [[Wikipedia:Fringe theories|content guideline]] declares: {{tq|the term fringe theory is used in a very broad sense to describe an idea that departs significantly from prevailing views or mainstream views ... a Wikipedia article should not make a fringe theory appear more notable or more widely accepted than it is ... examples include conspiracy theories.}} By presenting opposing narratives as if the Alternative were more plausible than the Official, this article tests the limits of [[WP:WEIGHT]]. [[User:NedFausa|NedFausa]] ([[User talk:NedFausa|talk]]) 17:22, 10 February 2021 (UTC)}}

=== [[Talk:2020 Nagorno-Karabakh war#rfc_30CB66B|Talk:2020 Nagorno-Karabakh war]] expired 2021-03-12 20:01 ===
* Id: 30CB66B
* User: ‘≥’°÷Ä’´’Ø ‘±’æ’°’£’µ’°’∂
* Date: 2021-02-27 08:26:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_style_and_naming|prev|1009204559|STYLE 1009204559}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_style_and_naming|prev|1011781175|STYLE 1011781175}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
I want to request comments from editors about changing positions of the countries on the infobox. In particular, changing sides from left to right and vice versa. In all the previous articles concerning the [[Nagorno-Karabakh conflict]], [[Armenia]] and [[Artsakh]] (Nagorno-Karabakh) were shown on the left side of the infobox and [[Azerbaijan]] on the right side. [https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/July_2020_Armenian‚ÄìAzerbaijani_clashes], [https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2016_Nagorno-Karabakh_conflict], [https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2014_Armenian‚ÄìAzerbaijani_clashes], [https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2012_Armenian‚ÄìAzerbaijani_border_clashes], [https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2010_Mardakert_clashes], [https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2010_Nagorno-Karabakh_clashes], [https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2008_Mardakert_clashes], [https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/First_Nagorno-Karabakh_War]. It comes from the fact that on the main map of military operations Armenia and Artsakh are on the left side and Azerbaijan on the right side respectively. 

I think it would be more correct if we switch the countries' position for [[2020 Nagorno-Karabakh war|this]] article as well: Armenia and Artsakh on the left side of the infobox, and Azerbaijan on the right. 

I would be glad to see other editors' opinions. 

Sincerely, [[User:‘≥’°÷Ä’´’Ø ‘±’æ’°’£’µ’°’∂|‘≥’°÷Ä’´’Ø ‘±’æ’°’£’µ’°’∂]] ([[User talk:‘≥’°÷Ä’´’Ø ‘±’æ’°’£’µ’°’∂|talk]]) 08:26, 27 February 2021 (UTC)}}

=== [[Talk:Eskimo kissing#rfc_BE4215C|Talk:Eskimo kissing]] expired 2021-03-16 23:01 ===
* Id: BE4215C
* User: DreamLinker
* Date: 2021-02-14 22:18:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Society,_sports,_and_culture|prev|1006811213|SOC 1006811213}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Society,_sports,_and_culture|prev|1012540919|SOC 1012540919}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
The current article is centred on the Western gesture called "Eskimo kiss" which is based on the "Kunik" gesture from Inuit culture. I am trying to solicit opinions from editors about how to change the article subject. Here are some suggestions -
* '''Option 1 - Change to Nose rub''' - Change to a general article about nose rub. Explain the various types of nose rubs in different cultures
* '''Option 2 - Centre on Eskimo kiss''' - Centre the article on the Western gesture called "Eskimo kiss" (explain anything else in context)
* '''Option 3 - Centre on Kunik''' - Centre the article on the Inuit gesture "Kunik" (explain anything else in context)
* '''Option 4 - Split Kunik into a new article''' - As Kunik may not the same as Eskimo kiss
(Suggestions are not limited to the options, any other suggestion is also welcome)--[[User:DreamLinker|DreamLinker]] ([[User talk:DreamLinker|talk]]) 22:18, 14 February 2021 (UTC)}}

=== [[Talk:Palestinian enclaves#rfc_A827138|Talk:Palestinian enclaves]] expired 2021-03-17 04:01 ===
* Id: A827138
* User: Wikieditor19920
* Date: 2021-02-15 03:08:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/History_and_geography|prev|1006851609|HIST 1006851609}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/History_and_geography|prev|1012578111|HIST 1012578111}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
The three questions below relate to the first paragraph of the lead, and how/if to present the "bantustan" analogy described regarding the proposed enclaves and racially segregated areas in apartheid South Africa. For those new to the discussion, please feel free to review the prior move discussion, which resulted in an article title change from "Palestinian bantustans" to "Palestinian enclaves."

<u>'''Question 1:'''</u> Should the lead make mention of the bantustans analogy?

<u>'''Question 2:'''</u> If yes to Q1, which one of the following three versions should be used to describe the analogy? (These are drawn from the prior three versions of the sentence present in the article. Please feel free to suggest slightly modified wording, but it would be helpful to indicate which is your closest preference based on the versions below.)

*'''A''' Critics of the enclave proposals have analogized them to the bantustans of apartheid South Africa, which were areas set aside for black inhabitants.
*'''B''' By way of the popular comparison between Israel and apartheid-era South Africa, the enclaves are also referred to as the '''West Bank bantustans'''.
*'''C''' The enclave models are, typically by critics, often referred to as bantustans, a term implying a comparison in this regard between Israel and apartheid-era South Africa, and figuratively as a Palestine Archipelago among other terms.

<u>'''Question 3:'''</u> Should "bantustans" be bolded as an alternative title?
[[User:Wikieditor19920|Wikieditor19920]] ([[User talk:Wikieditor19920|talk]]) 03:08, 15 February 2021 (UTC)}}

* User: Johnpacklambert

* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
 I am thinking we should go to requiring that every article be created by a registered editor. I also think that we should require that all editors submit their first new article through the Articles for Creation process, and we should not allow them to create any other new articles until they have successfully had one proposed article created through the AfC process.[[User:Johnpacklambert|John Pack Lambert]] ([[User talk:Johnpacklambert|talk]]) 16:38, 17 February 2021 (UTC)}}

=== [[Talk:Postcrossing#rfc_AB924E1|Talk:Postcrossing]] expired 2021-03-19 21:01 ===
* Id: AB924E1
* User: Dynamiccookies
* Date: 2021-02-17 20:20:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Society,_sports,_and_culture|prev|1007381665|SOC 1007381665}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Society,_sports,_and_culture|prev|1013067116|SOC 1013067116}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
Should the [[Postcrossing#Users_distribution|Users Distribution]] and [[Postcrossing#History|History]] tables include flags using the [[Wikipedia:WikiProject_Flag_Template|Project Flag Template]]? The argument is whether or not flags in these tables are merely decorative or actually serve a purpose.

Example: <nowiki>{{flag|USA}}</nowiki> -> {{flag|USA}}

Flags were initially included when the tables were first added to this page (Added Diffs: [https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Postcrossing&diff=next&oldid=548743316#Users_distribution Users Distribution] & [https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Postcrossing&diff=prev&oldid=548743316#History History]) back in April of 2013 by [[User:Starpromi|Starpromi]]. Then, recently, in January of 2021, [[User:MB|MB]] removed all of the flags (Removed Diffs: [https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Postcrossing&diff=next&oldid=1001497740#Users_distribution Users Distribution] & [https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Postcrossing&diff=next&oldid=1001498318#History History]) from the tables citing: {{code|rmv flag icons per [Manual of Style], purely decorational}}

I liked the flags in the tables but am torn between whether or not they were functional. I welcome you to review the [[Wikipedia:Manual_of_Style/Icons|Manual of Style/Icons page]] for yourself. More specifically, please review the [[Wikipedia:Manual_of_Style/Icons#Flags|Flags]] and [[Wikipedia:Manual_of_Style/Icons#Encyclopedic_purpose|Inappropriate use/Encyclopedic purpose]] sections before responding. - [[User:Dynamiccookies|<span style="color: maroon; text-shadow: 2px 2px 1px pink;">'''Dynamiccookies'''</span>]] <small>([[User talk:Dynamiccookies|talk]] | [[Special:Contributions/Dynamiccookies|contribs]])</small> 20:20, 17 February 2021 (UTC)}}

{{rfcquote|text=
The article has been protected not long ago to avoid the constant change of the pronouns on the plot section that refer to the character "Leon". I started [[Talk:Dog Day Afternoon#A note on the use of pronouns regarding the character "Leon", and the real person|a subsection]] on this talk page to have an open discussion about it, but still edits are being made without any commentary. Thus, I resort to [[Wikipedia:Requests for comment]] to have a discussion with other fellow users to reach the needed consensus. Some sort of notice can be added within the editing screen with the result to grant this article the stability that it deserves.--<span style="background:#75B2DD; padding:2px;">[[User:GDuwen|<b style="color:#E62020">GD</b><b style="color:#273BE2">uwen</b>]]</span>[[User talk:GDuwen|<b style="background:#318CE7; padding:2px; color:cyan"><small>Holler!</small></b>]] 13:43, 7 March 2021 (UTC)}}

=== [[Talk:L. L. Zamenhof#rfc_F0CFB6A|Talk:L. L. Zamenhof]] expired 2021-03-23 02:01 ===
* Id: F0CFB6A
* User: Khiikiat
* Date: 2021-02-21 01:15:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Biographies|prev|1008005205|BIO 1008005205}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/History_and_geography|prev|1008005213|HIST 1008005213}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Language_and_linguistics|prev|1008005217|LANG 1008005217}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Biographies|prev|1013716607|BIO 1013716607}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/History_and_geography|prev|1013716610|HIST 1013716610}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Language_and_linguistics|prev|1013716614|LANG 1013716614}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
Editors have been arguing about L. L. Zamenhof's nationality/ethnicity/citizenship for many years. Should we do the following?

*Change the first paragraph of the article to this: "'''L. L. Zamenhof''' (15 December 1859{{snd}}14 April 1917) was an [[ophthalmologist]] who lived for most of his life in [[Warsaw]]. He is best known as the creator of [[Esperanto]], the most widely used [[constructed language|constructed]] [[international auxiliary language]]."
*Remove the ''nationality'' parameter from the infobox.
*Create a new section entitled ''Nationality'' (before the ''Name'' section), where different points of view regarding Zamenhof's nationality/ethnicity/citizenship can be set out with appropriate references.

A similar approach has been taken in relation to [[Nicolaus Copernicus]] and [[Al-Farabi]]. [[User:Khiikiat|Khiikiat]] ([[User talk:Khiikiat|talk]]) 01:15, 21 February 2021 (UTC)}}

=== [[Talk:Michael J. Fox#rfc_BC58B62|Talk:Michael J. Fox]] expired 2021-03-24 06:01 ===
* Id: BC58B62
* User: Clear Looking Glass
* Date: 2021-03-01 06:36:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Biographies|prev|1009570500|BIO 1009570500}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Media,_the_arts,_and_architecture|prev|1009570503|MEDIA 1009570503}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Society,_sports,_and_culture|prev|1009570508|SOC 1009570508}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Biographies|prev|1013924697|BIO 1013924697}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Media,_the_arts,_and_architecture|prev|1013924703|MEDIA 1013924703}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Society,_sports,_and_culture|prev|1013924709|SOC 1013924709}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
 
How should the lede sentence refer to Michael J. Fox? Recently, there has been debate on what his lede should say, and I thought I'd get more opinions on this. Fox was born and raised in Canada, has dual Canadian and American citizenship, becoming a [https://www.hollywoodreporter.com/lists/14-hollywood-stars-who-immigrated-us-became-citizens-984824 U.S citizen in 2000], and has been described as being [https://www.cbc.ca/news/entertainment/michael-j-fox-q-a-1.4017957 "Canadian-American"]. Fox still [https://web.archive.org/web/20200810094035/https://www.theglobeandmail.com/arts/theatre-and-performance/michael-j-fox-martin-short-to-receive-governor-generals-lifetime-award/article34247469/ "strongly identifies"] as being Canadian, but has [https://www.nytimes.com/2020/11/13/books/michael-j-fox-no-time-like-the-future.html acknowledged] also having American citizenship (he's used it to vote) and currently [https://www.architecturaldigest.com/story/michael-j-fox-tracy-pollan-manhattan-home-article resides] in the United States.

#Canadian-American
#Canadian-born American
#Canadian and American
#Other? (for ex. - "Canadian-born" only) [[User:Clear Looking Glass|Clear Looking Glass]] ([[User talk:Clear Looking Glass|talk]]) 06:36, 1 March 2021 (UTC)}}

=== [[Talk:Breitbart News#rfc_3C103F8|Talk:Breitbart News]] expired 2021-03-26 11:01 ===
* Id: 3C103F8
* User: Adolphus79
* Date: 2021-02-24 10:19:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Economy,_trade,_and_companies|prev|1008653772|ECON 1008653772}}

{{rfcquote|text=
Which of these best describes Breitbart News Network/Breitbart News/Breitbart.com/Breitbart/etc.?
*'''Option 1:''' It is a news aggregator website, an organization or company without a publication, and the name(s) should not be italicized.
*'''Option 2:''' It is a publication, and therefore the name(s) should be italicized.
*'''Option 3:''' Some versions of the name reference the organization, but others reference a publication. (Please detail which should be italicized)

- [[User:Adolphus79|Adolphus79]] ([[User talk:Adolphus79|talk]]) 10:19, 24 February 2021 (UTC)}}

=== [[Wikipedia talk:Notability (books)#rfc_5374939|Wikipedia talk:Notability (books)]] expired 2021-03-26 11:01 ===
* Id: 5374939
* User: ReaderofthePack
* Date: 2021-02-24 10:08:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Media,_the_arts,_and_architecture|prev|1008653778|MEDIA 1008653778}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Media,_the_arts,_and_architecture|prev|1014309676|MEDIA 1014309676}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
I'm thinking that this could be viewed as a subset of the fourth criteria, if not both, at least. The phrasing for it as a criteria could be like this: 

* ''A book or short work is presumed notable if it has been reprinted by an academic or scholarly publisher known for its exclusivity and/or is affiliated with a reputable and notable educational institution, and which is not the original publisher of the work in question. The work must be reprinted in its entirety in book or journal format; newsletters or magazine do not qualify under this guideline.'' 

Adding it to the fourth criteria: 

* ''The book is, or has been, the subject of instruction at two or more schools, colleges, universities or post-graduate programs in any particular country. This includes the book or work being republished by academic or scholarly publishers known for their exclusivity and/or is affiliated with a reputable and notable educational institution, and which is not the original publisher of the work in question.'' 

Any other additions to make it more exclusive could be added in the notes section. Examples of notes could include: 

* ''Reprints of works through self-publishing companies, predatory journals or publishers, or mainstream and indie publishers do not satisfy the requirements for an academic or scholarly press. Reprints of journal articles or academic or scholarly papers do not qualify under this criteria.''

I also added that the publication must be attached to a well-known and notable university, as I figure this will help weed out anyone trying to skirt around this by launching "University of Billy Bob Press". [[User:ReaderofthePack|ReaderofthePack]]<small>(formerly Tokyogirl79)</small>[[User talk:ReaderofthePack|'''<span style="color:#19197; background:#fff;"> (ÔΩ°‚óï‚Äø‚óïÔΩ°)</span>''']] 10:08, 24 February 2021 (UTC)}}
