{{rfcquote|text=
i think the musician infobox is in great need of both the influence{s,d} parameters. that way we can trace pedigree of great musicians in the course of history.

it's no different than the scientist infobox. it gives us a great idea of who deserves to come before and after for specific musicians.

of course for jobber musicians it can be debated if they deserve this, but we can fight on those talk pages about whether they warrant them (maybe they're borderline [[WP:NOTABLE]] and thus don't deserve to piggyback on bigger names) [[Special:Contributions/198.53.108.48|198.53.108.48]] ([[User talk:198.53.108.48|talk]]) 01:38, 2 August 2021 (UTC)}}

=== [[Wikipedia:Reliable sources/Noticeboard#rfc_02B0EE9|Wikipedia:Reliable sources/Noticeboard]] expired 2021-08-16 06:01 ===
* Id: 02B0EE9
* User: Sdkb
* Date: 2021-08-12 17:15:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/WikiProjects_and_collaborations|prev|1038560936|PROJ 1038560936}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/WikiProjects_and_collaborations|prev|1043693264|PROJ 1043693264}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
As part of an effort to improve the links at {{tl|Find sources}} (something I'll be seeking further input on here once it gets farther along), I have been looking at newspapers commonly described as a [[newspaper of record]] for various countries. For Australia, the two publications most frequently cited are ''[[The Sydney Morning Herald]]'' and ''[[The Age]]'', sister papers in Melbourne and Sydney that share some articles. However, they're currently missing from RSP. So, how should these be seen?

*'''Option 1:''' The source is recognized as being [[WP:GREL|generally reliable]].
*'''Option 2:''' There is [[Wikipedia:MREL|no consensus or additional considerations apply]].
*'''Option 3:''' The source is recognized as being [[Wikipedia:GUNREL|generally unreliable]] in most cases, though it can be used under certain circumstances.
*'''Option 4:''' The source is recognized as being not reliable at all and should be [[Wikipedia:Deprecated sources|deprecated]].

Please indicate in your !vote whether it applies to the ''SMH'', ''The Age'', or both. <span style="color:#AAA"><small>&#123;{u&#124;</small><span style="border-radius:9em;padding:0 5px;background:#088">[[User:Sdkb|<span style="color:#FFF">'''Sdkb'''</span>]]</span><small>}&#125;</small></span>‚ÄØ<sup>[[User talk:Sdkb|'''talk''']]</sup> 17:15, 12 August 2021 (UTC)}}

=== [[Wikipedia:Village pump (proposals)#rfc_19D8951|Wikipedia:Village pump (proposals)]] expired 2021-08-16 12:01 ===
* Id: 19D8951
* User: Tzim78
* Date: 2021-08-13 22:05:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Biographies|prev|1038795809|BIO 1038795809}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Media,_the_arts,_and_architecture|prev|1038795816|MEDIA 1038795816}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Biographies|prev|1039057313|BIO 1039057313}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Media,_the_arts,_and_architecture|prev|1039057320|MEDIA 1039057320}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
Request to add info box parameter: '''existing works'''

'''Description''': the number of existing or surviving paintings, drawings, engravings or other attributed art works 

The following info box parameter would tell how many paintings survived.  For example El Greco has 500 existing paintings. 

This will help historians understand how many paintings are attributed to each artist, Monet has 2500 existing works.  

'''existing works''' = 500 paintings survived 

[[User:Tzim78|Tzim78]] ([[User talk:Tzim78|talk]]) 22:05, 13 August 2021 (UTC)}}

=== [[Talk:List of political parties in Italy#rfc_4FA3FB8|Talk:List of political parties in Italy]] expired 2021-08-18 15:01 ===
* Id: 4FA3FB8
* User: Scia Della Cometa
* Date: 2021-07-19 14:05:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Politics,_government,_and_law|prev|1034383212|POL 1034383212}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Politics,_government,_and_law|prev|1039410124|POL 1039410124}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
Hi. I would like to ask for your opinion about the reorganization of the '''defunct Italian parties'''. These parties are currently listed by dissolution date but divided into two lists (major and minor) and therefore into two chronological orders. I propose to list them by dissolution date <u>in a single chronological order</u>, eliminating the distinction between major and minor parties and adding the date of foundation and dissolution next to them in brackets. I propose eventually to divide them into institutional / political eras, as in the pages on the parties of other countries, for example: ''"Kingdom of Italy (1845‚Äì1946)"'', ''"First Republic (1946‚Äì1994)"'', ''"Second Republic (since 1994)"''. Please give an opinion!--[[User:Scia Della Cometa|Scia Della Cometa]] ([[User talk:Scia Della Cometa|talk]]) 14:05, 19 July 2021 (UTC)}}

=== [[Talk:Persecution of Christians#rfc_97FEF67|Talk:Persecution of Christians]] expired 2021-08-19 15:01 ===
* Id: 97FEF67
* User: Jenhawk777
* Date: 2021-08-15 19:43:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Religion_and_philosophy|prev|1039045570|RELI 1039045570}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Religion_and_philosophy|prev|1039584748|RELI 1039584748}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
See above discussion. 

All Reliable Sources refer to James the Just as a martyr. No one argues that James was not killed for his faith. WP defines [[Martyr]] as someone who suffers persecution and death for their beliefs. A martyrdom is not an ordinary death. I think that means ''all reliable sources'' say James the Just suffered persecution and death for his faith. Slatersteven believes the word persecution must be used and that martyrdom is not a sufficient simile for persecution to include James the Just here in this article [[Persecution of Christians]]. 

The question is: does the term martyrdom include the concept of persecution? [[User:Jenhawk777|Jenhawk777]] ([[User talk:Jenhawk777|talk]]) 19:43, 15 August 2021 (UTC)}}

=== [[Wikipedia:Reliable sources/Noticeboard#rfc_370414A|Wikipedia:Reliable sources/Noticeboard]] expired 2021-08-22 09:01 ===
* Id: 370414A
* User: Sdkb
* Date: 2021-08-12 18:09:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/WikiProjects_and_collaborations|prev|1038543092|PROJ 1038543092}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/WikiProjects_and_collaborations|prev|1040041921|PROJ 1040041921}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
''[[The Straits Times]]'' is the largest newspaper in Singapore. How should we consider its reliability?

*'''Option 1:''' The source is recognized as being [[WP:GREL|generally reliable]].
*'''Option 2:''' There is [[Wikipedia:MREL|no consensus or additional considerations apply]].
*'''Option 3:''' The source is recognized as being [[Wikipedia:GUNREL|generally unreliable]] in most cases, though it can be used under certain circumstances.
*'''Option 4:''' The source is recognized as being not reliable at all and should be [[Wikipedia:Deprecated sources|deprecated]].
<span style="color:#AAA"><small>&#123;{u&#124;</small><span style="border-radius:9em;padding:0 5px;background:#088">[[User:Sdkb|<span style="color:#FFF">'''Sdkb'''</span>]]</span><small>}&#125;</small></span>‚ÄØ<sup>[[User talk:Sdkb|'''talk''']]</sup> 18:09, 12 August 2021 (UTC)}}

=== [[Wikipedia talk:WikiProject Religion/Notability guide#rfc_86A6412|Wikipedia talk:WikiProject Religion/Notability guide]] expired 2021-08-23 16:01 ===
* Id: 86A6412
* User: 4meter4
* Date: 2021-07-24 15:47:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_policies_and_guidelines|prev|1035257148|POLICY 1035257148}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_policies_and_guidelines|prev|1040271327|POLICY 1040271327}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
This essay has repeatedly and historically been cited as policy at [[WP:Articles for Deletion]], but it is not actually an official policy endorsed as an [[WP:SNG]]. Likewise [[WP:CLERGYOUTCOMES]], has widely been cited at AFD without an underlying SNG supporting it as policy. It's my opinion that both this guide and [[WP:CLERGYOUTCOMES]] needs input from the wider community and not just editors who work frequently in this content area. I personally don't think religious leaders should be exempt from meeting the threshold of [[WP:SIGCOV]], and that presumed notability as indicated here should be overturned. Likewise the pro-Catholic and anti other religious sects bias in the policy is problematic as written and I think needs some scrutiny. If the community disagrees, then this guide or something similar should become an officially endorsed SNG rather than being an essay that in all practical purposes has been acting like an official SNG. Rather than crafting a proposal for voting off the bat, I would like to hear other's opinions first in order to craft a proposal that is likely to pass. Best.[[User:4meter4|4meter4]] ([[User talk:4meter4|talk]]) 15:47, 24 July 2021 (UTC)}}

=== [[Wikipedia:Reliable sources/Noticeboard#rfc_5E0B94D|Wikipedia:Reliable sources/Noticeboard]] expired 2021-08-28 00:01 ===
* Id: 5E0B94D
* User: Sdkb
* Date: 2021-08-12 18:09:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/WikiProjects_and_collaborations|prev|1038567289|PROJ 1038567289}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/WikiProjects_and_collaborations|prev|1041003892|PROJ 1041003892}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
The ''[[New Zealand Herald]]'' is a daily newspaper based in [[Auckland]] and the largest newspaper in New Zealand. How should we consider its reliability?

*'''Option 1:''' The source is recognized as being [[WP:GREL|generally reliable]].
*'''Option 2:''' There is [[Wikipedia:MREL|no consensus or additional considerations apply]].
*'''Option 3:''' The source is recognized as being [[Wikipedia:GUNREL|generally unreliable]] in most cases, though it can be used under certain circumstances.
*'''Option 4:''' The source is recognized as being not reliable at all and should be [[Wikipedia:Deprecated sources|deprecated]].
<span style="color:#AAA"><small>&#123;{u&#124;</small><span style="border-radius:9em;padding:0 5px;background:#088">[[User:Sdkb|<span style="color:#FFF">'''Sdkb'''</span>]]</span><small>}&#125;</small></span>‚ÄØ<sup>[[User talk:Sdkb|'''talk''']]</sup> 18:09, 12 August 2021 (UTC)}}

=== [[Talk:Pahonia#rfc_1CE4302|Talk:Pahonia]] expired 2021-08-28 21:01 ===
* Id: 1CE4302
* User: Gedzimin
* Date: 2021-08-28 18:36:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/History_and_geography|prev|1041129040|HIST 1041129040}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/History_and_geography|prev|1041144212|HIST 1041144212}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
From my objective view, the changes that made English wiki article [[Pahonia]] redirect to [[Coat of Arms of Lithuania]] are mistaken. Emblem Pahonia was official emblem of [[Belarusian People's Republic]] in 1918 and [[Republic of Belarus]] in 1991-1995. It has no relevance to current "[[Vytis]]" of Lithuania. It also has no relevance to [[Coat of arms of Lithuania]]. That's why Pahonia has to be returned, as it also offends belarusians, 'cause this is officially intangible historical and cultural value  of Belarus, same as the national emblem of Belarus.

The emblem also has [[Slavic]] roots and name<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.belarusguide.com/as/history/pahonia.html}}</ref>. And is official emblem of [[Grand Duchy of Lithuania|Grand duchy of Lithuania, Ruthenia, and Samogitia]]. Both Lithuania and Belarus are successors of the state, although emblem Pahonia([[Latin-language|lat.]] ''pogonia'', [[Ruthenian language|ruth.]] ''–ü–æ–≥–æ–Ω—è'') was ''mostly'' considered as slavic. Most of voivodeships in [[Grand Duchy of Lithuania|GDL]] that were on the territories of modern Belarus have Pahonia on it<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.heraldicum.ru/lietuva/voevod.htm}}</ref>. 

‚Ä¶ According to ancient custom, the pursuit of the enemy is the duty of every man in our land; such a joint movement for the expulsion of the enemy from our Lithuanian land is popularly(by people) called "pogonia". - [[Jagailo]] in his privilegium of February 20, 1387.

Lithuanian names Vykimas and [[Vytis]] are [[Neologism|neologisms]], created in late XVIII-XIX centuries. None of official or unofficial documents of [[Grand Duchy of Lithuania|GDL]] or foreign countries have ever mentioned these names. And Vykimas is literal translation of Pogonia in lithuanian. [[User:Gedzimin|Gedzimin]] ([[User talk:Gedzimin|talk]]) 18:36, 28 August 2021 (UTC)}}

=== [[Talk:Persecution of Christians#rfc_C15F728|Talk:Persecution of Christians]] expired 2021-08-29 01:01 ===
* Id: C15F728
* User: Slatersteven
* Date: 2021-08-24 15:16:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Religion_and_philosophy|prev|1040446026|RELI 1040446026}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Religion_and_philosophy|prev|1041171298|RELI 1041171298}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
Josephus reports in the Antiquities of the Jews that High Priest Ananus ben Ananus took advantage of the death of Roman procurator Porcius Festus to have James the Just and others stoned to death. This act angered the new procurator Lucceius Albinus and the Jewish king Herod Agrippa II, who had Ananus deposed and replaced by Jesus ben Damneus.

And 

The first official hostile act of the Empire towards Jewish-Christians happened under the reign of Claudius: according to the Acts of the Apostles[2] and ancient historians Suetonius, Cassius Dio and Orosius, Claudius had both Jews and Jewish-Christians expelled from Rome because they were causing disturbances. Both groups were re-admitted in the Capital after Claudius's death.[[User:Slatersteven|Slatersteven]] ([[User talk:Slatersteven|talk]]) 15:16, 24 August 2021 (UTC)}}

=== [[Talk:Nicki Minaj#rfc_F4B2E6D|Talk:Nicki Minaj]] expired 2021-08-30 03:01 ===
* Id: F4B2E6D
* User: RogueShanghai
* Date: 2021-08-21 11:38:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Biographies|prev|1039964150|BIO 1039964150}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Biographies|prev|1045402561|BIO 1045402561}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
How do we correctly mention that Nicki Minaj has been called the [[Honorific nicknames in popular music|"Queen of Hip-Hop"]] by reputable publications such as [https://www.nytimes.com/2015/08/30/arts/music/2015-mtv-vmas.html The New York Times,] [https://www.billboard.com/articles/events/hot-100-festival/6633571/nicki-minaj-hot-100-festival-timeline Billboard,] [https://www.nytimes.com/2017/10/16/t-magazine/nicki-minaj.html T Magazine] [https://www.npr.org/2018/10/03/651761719/nicki-minaj-is-the-21st-centurys-insatiable-hip-hop-monarch NPR,] [https://www.latimes.com/entertainment/music/posts/la-et-ms-bet-experience-2015-nicki-minaj-fails-to-impress-20150627-story.html LA Times,] [https://www.mtv.com/news/1829711/who-is-nicki-minaj-talking-to-on-pills-n-potions/ MTV,] [https://www.xxlmag.com/nicki-minaj-essential-songs XXL,] and [https://www.thedailybeast.com/articles/2015/12/10/nicki-minaj-and-meek-mill-s-crazy-2015 The Daily Beast], whilst keeping it balanced and not over-puffed? In my opinion, it's perfectly possible to make note of in the lead that she's been called the "Queen of Hip-Hop" and the "Queen of Rap" by reputable news sources while still following [[WP:NPOV]] and being fair, minimalist, and concise. I'm pinging some people of note in the earlier discussion and also those who can comment: {{reply to|Cybertrip|Jurisdicta|AshMusique|Cullen328|VersaceSpace|CAMERAwMUSTACHE|MarioSoulTruthFan|Yikes2004|SunriseInBrooklyn|Blarb48}}

[[User:RogueShanghai/sandbox|Here is my proposed biography]] (open to suggestions and changes, and implemented some ideas in the earlier RfC discussion) that tries to keep a balance between this moniker and keeping the lead balanced. Thank you. [[User:RogueShanghai|<span style="font-family: Kristen ITC; color:#e91db1">"Pop pills now we Shanghai!"</span>]]<sup>[[User talk:RogueShanghai|<span style="font-family:Kristen ITC; color:#e91db1">(talk to me!~)</span>]]</sup> 11:38, 21 August 2021 (UTC)}}

=== [[Talk:Keith Urban#rfc_5444FA0|Talk:Keith Urban]] expired 2021-08-31 01:01 ===
* Id: 5444FA0
* User: JDDJS
* Date: 2021-08-01 00:39:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Biographies|prev|1036509765|BIO 1036509765}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Biographies|prev|1041523295|BIO 1041523295}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
There have been some discussions about what nationality to list in the lead, but none that have had a lot of discussion. Listing three different nationalities is rarely done. The facts to keep in mind: he was born in New Zealand, however it's unclear if he has New Zealand citizenship because New Zealand doesn't have birthright citizenship. The article currently states that he does have New Zealand citizenship, but it is tagged as citation needed. Urban moved to Australia at a young age, grew up there, and started his career there and is sourced to have Australian citizenship. Urban's career however, didn't really take off until he moved to America in the 90s. Some time before the 2016 US election, Urban became an American citizen and voted in America for the first time that year. In [https://thehill.com/blogs/in-the-know/in-the-know/328373-country-music-star-keith-urban-unsure-if-hed-accept-invitation this article], he says he has dual Australian-American citizenship, with no mention of New Zealand. With this in mind, which of the following options do you think is best to use in the lead? (If you have an alternative option, feel free to add it)
*'''Option 1''' ''New Zealand-born Australian-American'' 
*'''Option 2''' ''New Zealand-born Australian''
*'''Option 3''' ''Australian-American''
*'''Option 4''' ''Australian''
*'''Option 5''' don't list any specific nationality in the lead sentence, but explain his complicated nationality in the lead paragraph. 

<span style="color:green;">[[User:JDDJS|<span style="color:green;">JDDJS</span>]] ([[User talk:JDDJS|<span style="color:purple;">talk to me</span>]] ‚Ä¢ [[Special:Contributions/JDDJS|<span style="color:purple;">see what I've done</span>]])</span> 00:39, 1 August 2021 (UTC)}}

=== [[Wikipedia:Village pump (policy)#rfc_FDBC30C|Wikipedia:Village pump (policy)]] expired 2021-08-31 16:01 ===
* Id: FDBC30C
* Date: 2021-08-18 19:30:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_policies_and_guidelines|prev|1039337668|POLICY 1039337668}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_policies_and_guidelines|prev|1041630824|POLICY 1041630824}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
'''Proposed modification''' to [[WP:BLOCK]]: 

That once an account is blocked by an administrator, other administrators must wait at least 24 hours before unblocking that account.

During the initial 24 hours, the account may only be unblocked by the initial blocking administrator or due to community consensus.

While unblock may be requested at any time by the account blocked, as normal - as stated above, during the initial 24 hours, the request can not be approved except by the initial blocking admin, or by community consensus.

(Note: This does not affect anything ‚Äúabove‚Äù the admin level, like arbcom taking over a block, or steward action, etc.) 

------------------------------
'''Added for clarity:''' The initially blocking admin (just like the community) can obviously give consent that some other uninvolved admin may unblock during that initial 24 hour period (such as specifically asking for help with a technical blocking issue). In such a case, they do not have to be the one to actually press the unblock button. They can also set clear criteria for unblocking, such as: "If xyz is done, then any uninvolved admin may unblock", such as in the case of a username block.. - <b>[[User:Jc37|jc37]]</b> 19:30, 18 August 2021 (UTC)}}

=== [[Talk:Body mass index#rfc_C572670|Talk:Body mass index]] expired 2021-09-02 00:01 ===
* Id: C572670
* User: Jroberson108
* Date: 2021-08-02 23:26:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Maths,_science,_and_technology|prev|1036833348|SCI 1036833348}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_style_and_naming|prev|1036833355|STYLE 1036833355}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_policies_and_guidelines|prev|1036833360|POLICY 1036833360}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Maths,_science,_and_technology|prev|1041865427|SCI 1041865427}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_style_and_naming|prev|1041865432|STYLE 1041865432}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_policies_and_guidelines|prev|1041865434|POLICY 1041865434}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
BMI categories are defined by ranges of numbers per this reliable source ([https://apps.who.int/iris/bitstream/handle/10665/43190/9241593024_eng.pdf The SuRF Report 2], p. 22), which uses two decimal precision (e.g. Overweight: 25.00-29.99; Obese I: 30.00-34.99). Some feel "29.999", etc. are "gaps" unaccounted for that can cause confusion and feel it unscientific and want to include all numbers by rounding the upper limits/boundaries (25-30; 30-35) implying ranges that exclude the upper limit (30 and 35 respectively) and barely "touch" the next category's lower limit. Others feel worrying about "29.99X" unnecessary, [[MOS:RANGE]] includes the upper limit, "30" in two categories is inaccurate and a confusing "overlap", and we should stick to [[WP:RS]] with one decimal precision being clear enough (25.0-29.9; 30.0-34.9). The latter is presently on the article page (see [[Body_mass_index#Categories|Categories]]) along with explanatory footnotes ([[Template:Efn|efn]]) with text of "After rounding." added to each BMI table in their column headers to accommodate "gap" concerns. The opinions have not budged after discussion. [[User:Jroberson108|Jroberson108]] ([[User talk:Jroberson108|talk]]) 23:26, 2 August 2021 (UTC)}}

=== [[Template talk:Infobox comics character#rfc_B65783D|Template talk:Infobox comics character]] expired 2021-09-02 01:01 ===

=== [[Talk:Holodomor in modern politics#rfc_B610C17|Talk:Holodomor in modern politics]] expired 2021-09-02 15:01 ===
* Id: B610C17
* User: Stix1776
* Date: 2021-05-30 08:09:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Politics,_government,_and_law|prev|1032382102|POL 1032382102}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Politics,_government,_and_law|prev|1041964683|POL 1041964683}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
 
{{User:ClueBot III/DoNotArchiveUntil|1628604086}}
There's been a difficultly amongst editors regarding the statement "Sixty-nine states have signed declarations in statements at the UNGA affirming that the Holodomor was as a 'national tragedy of the Ukrainian people'..." The issue is whether it is OK to count the number of countries from the UN General Assembly statements from 4 documents [https://undocs.org/A/C.3/58/9], [https://undocs.org/A/C.3/58/9/Add.1], [https://undocs.org/A/63/613], [https://undocs.org/A/68/655], and [https://undocs.org/A/73/630]. No primary or secondary sources lists the count, however per [[WP:CALC]] routine calculations are allowed.

To be honest, I was the skeptical editor and didn't trust the 69 number for the longest time. It's an utter pain trying to calculate all the unique countries, so I wrote a Python script to do it[https://pastebin.com/cQ4vVzTu]. I'm still not 100% sure if I'm correct. I've never seen a page try to do this, so I'm worried that it's OR.

There are a few options:
*'''A: Keep the text as 69 (or 70), explicitly listing the number'''
*'''B: Write "at least 69 (or 70)"'''
*'''C: Change it to "many countries" or something similar''' [[User:Stix1776|Stix1776]] ([[User talk:Stix1776|talk]]) 08:09, 30 May 2021 (UTC)}}

=== [[Talk:Pan Sophic#rfc_9E9E50D|Talk:Pan Sophic]] expired 2021-09-03 05:01 ===
* Id: 9E9E50D
* User: FormalDude
* Date: 2021-09-01 21:30:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Society,_sports,_and_culture|prev|1041852103|SOC 1041852103}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Society,_sports,_and_culture|prev|1042091693|SOC 1042091693}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
Which picture should be used for the infobox image?<br>
'''Option A:''' [[:File:The crest of Pan Sophic.png]]<br>
'''Option B:''' [[:File:Pan Sophic Fraternity Crest.png]]

=== [[Wikipedia talk:No personal attacks#rfc_D903B90|Wikipedia talk:No personal attacks]] expired 2021-09-05 09:01 ===
* Id: D903B90
* User: MarshallKe
* Date: 2021-09-01 00:49:00

* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
Per the discussion [[Wikipedia_talk:No_personal_attacks#Adding spirituality as a group of people that shouldn't be targeted by personal attacks]], more than one editor expressed the desire to reduce this list rather than expand it. I propose we remove exactly one item from this list. The options are: race, sex, gender identity, sexual orientation, age, religious beliefs, political beliefs, disability, ethnicity, and nationality. [[User:MarshallKe|MarshallKe]] ([[User talk:MarshallKe|talk]]) 00:49, 1 September 2021 (UTC)}}

=== [[Talk:Elvis Presley#rfc_4E45D95|Talk:Elvis Presley]] expired 2021-09-08 13:01 ===
* Id: 4E45D95
* User: Emily19911991
* Date: 2021-09-08 11:10:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Unsorted|prev|1043113921|UNSORTED 1043113921}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Unsorted|prev|1043121876|UNSORTED 1043121876}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
I would like some other editors to comment on what seems to me a rather bizarre claim made by User:Bluesatellite about ‚ÄúElvis‚Äù allegedly not being a mononym. I have tried to use tbe talk page and converse with the user, but he just keeps removing the information from the article, and simply expressed an opinion without any sources to back up his claim. Oh, and to make matters worse, he has had the audacity to warn me on my talk page. Anyway, according to the user, if ‚ÄúElvis‚Äù were a mononym then the title of the article would only be ‚ÄúElvis‚Äù, but that isn‚Äôt the definition of a mononym. A mononymous person is someone known by a single name and Elvis Presley since he became a global superstar in the 1950s has been known by his unusual name Elvis without any need for his surname to be mentioned. The information ‚Äúalso known simply as Elvis‚Äù has been included in the article as far back as 2019 without any problems whatsoever. User:Bluesatellite made the false analogy between Elvis Presley and Mariah Carey - the former has always been known by his first name whereas the latter has always been known by her full name. There are lots of mononymous people that people know the surnames of as well - Oprah (Winfrey), Kylie (Minogue), Beyonc√© (Knowles), etc. I have provided reliable sources stating that ‚ÄúElvis‚Äù is a mononym and that his surname ‚ÄúPresley‚Äù was explicitly omitted to make that point. Go anywhere in the world and say ‚ÄúElvis‚Äù and people will know which person you are on about straightaway. The [[Kylie Minogue]] article and many other articles (see above) state ‚Äúalso known simply as‚Äù followed by that person‚Äôs name. The user‚Äôs false analogy and opinions are not relevant or carry any weight - I have provided reliable sources to back up the claim and I don‚Äôt see why someone is trying to create a problem that isn‚Äôt even there.--[[User:Emily19911991|Emily19911991]] ([[User talk:Emily19911991|talk]]) 11:10, 8 September 2021 (UTC)}}

=== [[Talk:Ramones#rfc_CAC30F7|Talk:Ramones]] expired 2021-09-08 15:01 ===
* Id: CAC30F7
* User: ILIL
* Date: 2021-08-23 20:50:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Media,_the_arts,_and_architecture|prev|1040314457|MEDIA 1040314457}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_style_and_naming|prev|1040314465|STYLE 1040314465}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_policies_and_guidelines|prev|1040314466|POLICY 1040314466}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Media,_the_arts,_and_architecture|prev|1043139328|MEDIA 1043139328}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_style_and_naming|prev|1043139334|STYLE 1043139334}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_policies_and_guidelines|prev|1043139338|POLICY 1043139338}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
There is a longtime dispute regarding the first sentence of [[Ramones]], specifically, whether it should begin as "{{tq|The '''Ramones'''}}" or "{{tq|'''Ramones'''}}". [[WP:THE|Current policy regarding the naming conventions of music groups]] doesn't appear to adequately address disputes regarding the use of [[definite articles]] in an unofficial capacity.

It's universally agreed that the band is officially known as "Ramones" because that is how they are credited on their CDS, audiotapes, and records. However, most other publications refer to this band as "the Ramones". Interviews reveal that the members of the group also refer to their band with a definite article in everyday speech. [https://www.artistwd.com/joyzine/music/ramones/joey.php] [https://punkrockinterviews.com/interview-with-marky-ramone-from-the-remainz-the-ramones/] Other articles, such as [[Electric Light Orchestra]] and [[Nazz]], take the same approach being proposed in this RfC.

This is not an RfC about changing the title of the article, but in how Wikipedia writes about this band and others with similar naming disputes. In the survey, please answer '''Yes''' or '''No''' in reference to the title question. [[User:ILIL|ili]] ([[User talk:ILIL|talk]]) 20:50, 23 August 2021 (UTC)}}

=== [[Talk:Muhammad Ali of Egypt#rfc_F2A950D|Talk:Muhammad Ali of Egypt]] expired 2021-09-09 00:01 ===
* Id: F2A950D
* User: Haldir Marchwarden
* Date: 2021-09-07 12:40:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Biographies|prev|1042924214|BIO 1042924214}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Biographies|prev|1043218348|BIO 1043218348}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
One user (me) has added content backed by sources about the origins of the subject, for which all agree there is no actual evidence (with the exception of a document located in Turkey, whose existence is disputed; and a tradition in the subject's family). At least two users oppose this addition because they say the sources are misused, unreliable, and self-published. They claim the first user (me) is "abusing bibliography". The first user (me) argues that it is not true that the sources are misused, unreliable, and self-published, that bibliography isn't being abused, and that all viewpoints whose existence is proven by multiple reliable sources must be included in the article, especially considering that the origins of the subject are unknown, and that he was born in a place different from the claimed ethnicities (Greece) and is chiefly important to yet another country (Egypt).--[[User:Haldir Marchwarden|Haldir Marchwarden]] ([[User talk:Haldir Marchwarden|talk]]) 12:40, 7 September 2021 (UTC)}}

=== [[Talk:Pythagorean triple#rfc_1976C93|Talk:Pythagorean triple]] expired 2021-09-09 10:01 ===
* Id: 1976C93
* User: Selfstudier
* Date: 2021-08-10 09:10:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Language_and_linguistics|prev|1038070360|LANG 1038070360}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Maths,_science,_and_technology|prev|1038070363|SCI 1038070363}}

** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Maths,_science,_and_technology|prev|1043290560|SCI 1043290560}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
An RFC (above) has determined that the paper at Reference 3 below should be considered as a primary source. Should the following (or something similar or anything at all) be included in the article body?
According to Dr.Daniel Mansfield, a researcher at [[University of New South Wales|UNSW Sydney]],<ref>{{cite web|title=Dr. Daniel Francis Mansfield|url=https://research.unsw.edu.au/people/dr-daniel-francis-mansfield|access-date= 6 August 2021}}</ref> speaking about the "surveyor's tablet" [[Si.427]] and its relationship with [[Plimpton 322]], "The rectangles are perfect". The surveyor achieved this by using Pythagorean triples.<ref>{{cite news|title= Babylonians calculated with triangles centuries before Pythagoras|url= https://www.newscientist.com/article/2285917-babylonians-calculated-with-triangles-centuries-before-pythagoras/|date=4 August 2021|access-date=7 August 2021}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal | author = Daniel F. Mansfield | title = Plimpton 322: A Study of Rectangles | journal = Foundations of Science | year = 2021 | doi = 10.1007/s10699-021-09806-0 }}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://news.unsw.edu.au/en/australian-mathematician-reveals-oldest-applied-geometry|title=Australian Mathematician reveals oldest applied geometry|website=news.unsw.edu.au}}</ref>{{reftalk}}
[[User:Selfstudier|Selfstudier]] ([[User talk:Selfstudier|talk]]) 09:10, 10 August 2021 (UTC)}}

'''Should Trump be described as a conspiracy theorist in the [[MOS:LEAD|lede]]?'''<br>

* User: RogueShanghai

{{rfcquote|text=
Should we use Vice Ganda's last name, ''Viceral,'' or his stage name, ''Vice Ganda'', to refer to him in the article? "Viceral" as a last name is not really a last name that is notable for Vice Ganda, with not many people knowing her by said last name. There are also instances in articles where a stage name is used to refer to someone instead of their real last name, namely, [[Megan Thee Stallion]]. Would like to hear people's thoughts on this, thanks. [[User:RogueShanghai|<span style="background-color: black; color:#ff5a5a; padding: 3px 4px 2px 4px;">'''''shanghai.'''''</span>]]<sup>[[User talk:RogueShanghai|<span style="background-color: black; color:#ff5a5a; padding: 3px">talk to me</span>]]</sup> 09:13, 6 September 2021 (UTC)}}

=== [[Talk:List of Muay Thai practitioners#rfc_B2400B7|Talk:List of Muay Thai practitioners]] expired 2021-09-10 09:01 ===
* Id: B2400B7
* User: Imcdc
* Date: 2021-09-10 01:22:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Society,_sports,_and_culture|prev|1043424773|SOC 1043424773}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Society,_sports,_and_culture|prev|1043480691|SOC 1043480691}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
There are fighters in this list like [[Anderson Silva]] and [[Jos√© Aldo]] who use Muay Thai heavily in their MMA fighters.
However I'm not sure if they can be still considered "Muay Thai based fighters" because they also trained a lot in other areas.

This is in contrast to fighters like [[Valentina Shevchenko]] and [[Joanna Jƒôdrzejczyk]] where we can see have spent a lot of time in  Muay Thai itself gain huge accomplishments before switching to Mixed Martial Arts.

Should we allow fighters in the former to appear in this list or keep it strictly to only fighters from the latter?

-[[User:Imcdc|Imcdc]] ([[User talk:Imcdc|talk]]) 01:22, 10 September 2021 (UTC)}}

=== [[Wikipedia:Reliable sources/Noticeboard#rfc_D262840|Wikipedia:Reliable sources/Noticeboard]] expired 2021-09-11 13:01 ===
* Id: D262840
* User: Sdkb
* Date: 2021-08-12 18:09:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/WikiProjects_and_collaborations|prev|1038649926|PROJ 1038649926}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/WikiProjects_and_collaborations|prev|1043693264|PROJ 1043693264}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
The ''[[Mail & Guardian]]'' is a weekly newspaper based in [[Johannesburg]]. How should we consider its reliability?

*'''Option 1:''' The source is recognized as being [[WP:GREL|generally reliable]].
*'''Option 2:''' There is [[Wikipedia:MREL|no consensus or additional considerations apply]].
*'''Option 3:''' The source is recognized as being [[Wikipedia:GUNREL|generally unreliable]] in most cases, though it can be used under certain circumstances.
*'''Option 4:''' The source is recognized as being not reliable at all and should be [[Wikipedia:Deprecated sources|deprecated]].
<span style="color:#AAA"><small>&#123;{u&#124;</small><span style="border-radius:9em;padding:0 5px;background:#088">[[User:Sdkb|<span style="color:#FFF">'''Sdkb'''</span>]]</span><small>}&#125;</small></span>‚ÄØ<sup>[[User talk:Sdkb|'''talk''']]</sup> 18:09, 12 August 2021 (UTC)}}

=== [[Talk:2022 South Korean presidential election#rfc_901D38B|Talk:2022 South Korean presidential election]] expired 2021-09-13 23:01 ===
* Id: 901D38B
* User: Helper201
* Date: 2021-08-14 22:03:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Politics,_government,_and_law|prev|1038817114|POL 1038817114}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Politics,_government,_and_law|prev|1044171472|POL 1044171472}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
Should we remove the minor parties and independents section? The [[National Revolutionary Dividends Party]] has no elected representation at any level in South Korea and from what I can see from the opinion polls their candidate hasn't even appeared in any polls. As for the [[Progressive Party (South Korea, 2017)|Progressive Party]] we don't even have a confirmed candidate for them and they also have no elected members in the National Assembly. The Progressive Party's predecessor ([[People's United Party (South Korea)]]) finished in 8th place in the last South Korean presidential election in 2017 with 0.08% of the vote. These parties don't seem to be notable in this election unless their candidates at least begin to appear in opinion polls. The citation for the National Revolutionary Dividends Party may also be a first party source although I'm not sure and as for the Progressive Party we don't even have a citation talking about them running in this election or any of their potential candidates. I'd argue its better we remove this section, for without any criteria the page could become overloaded with a host of extremely minor parties and independents that will likely have very little, if any, impact in the election. [[User:Helper201|Helper201]] ([[User talk:Helper201|talk]]) 22:03, 14 August 2021 (UTC)}}

=== [[Wikipedia talk:WikiProject Elections and Referendums#rfc_64975AC|Wikipedia talk:WikiProject Elections and Referendums]] expired 2021-09-15 22:01 ===
* Id: 64975AC
* User: MrOinkingPig
* Date: 2021-08-16 21:02:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/History_and_geography|prev|1039133377|HIST 1039133377}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Politics,_government,_and_law|prev|1039133386|POL 1039133386}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/History_and_geography|prev|1044560729|HIST 1044560729}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Politics,_government,_and_law|prev|1044560733|POL 1044560733}}
* RFC Text:

'''Background:'''

Currently, a candidate must receive more than 5% to appear in most US election infoboxes. This is a good standard and I do not agree with changing it. 

'''Proposal:'''

If a candidate wins a county in a statewide election, they should appear in the infobox. Currently, winning a county doesn't necessarily guarantee that a candidate goes in the infobox. This results in the candidate's name appearing in the map caption but no other information like their % of the vote, # of votes, party, picture, and full name. For example, the [[1976 United States Senate election in Virginia]] saw Martin Perper win a county but not appear in the infobox due to only receiving 4.5% of the vote. This makes the infobox a bit confusing to look at because there is no other mention of Perper besides the map caption

This would be an easy change to make because only a few elections have seen candidates win counties and not get more than 5% of the vote. [[User:MrOinkingPig|MrOinkingPig]] ([[User talk:MrOinkingPig|talk]]) 21:02, 16 August 2021 (UTC)}}

=== [[Wikipedia talk:WikiProject Elections and Referendums#rfc_2135955|Wikipedia talk:WikiProject Elections and Referendums]] expired 2021-09-15 22:01 ===
* Id: 2135955
* User: Twotwofourtysix
* Date: 2021-09-02 23:32:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Politics,_government,_and_law|prev|1042052346|POL 1042052346}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Politics,_government,_and_law|prev|1047867884|POL 1047867884}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
Given that {{Useranon|67.173.23.66}} removes images of candidates in the primaries sections of many, many articles citing that "photos generally aren't included for non presidential elections" and that "No such images are present on any gubernatorial elections for earlier years," should U.S. election articles, especially U.S. Senate and gubernatorial election articles in 2022, include galleries of images for the candidates in the Democratic/Republican primaries sections? <span class="nowrap">'' ‚Äî[[User:Twotwofourtysix|<span style="color:#9C59D1">twotwofourtysix</span>]]<sup>(My [[User talk:Twotwofourtysix|talk page]] and [[Special:Contributions/Twotwofourtysix|contributions]])</sup>''</span> 23:32, 2 September 2021 (UTC)}}


=== [[Wikipedia:Reliable sources/Noticeboard#rfc_1E13FFA|Wikipedia:Reliable sources/Noticeboard]] expired 2021-09-16 05:01 ===
* Id: 1E13FFA
* User: David Gerard
* Date: 2021-09-04 17:05:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_proposals|prev|1042380964|PROP 1042380964}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_proposals|prev|1044614854|PROP 1044614854}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
Newsblaze claims to be a news site: "the alternative business and world news newspaper". https://newsblaze.com/ and https://newsblaze.com.au/  There are presently [https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?search=insource%3A%22newsblaze%22&title=Special:Search&profile=advanced&fulltext=1&ns0=1 348 usages] in article space.

The [https://newsblaze.com/newsblaze-in-the-news-pressroom/ pressroom page] states: "Newsblaze was founded with the goal of giving attention to the news that the mainstream media gives little or no time." 

There are editors concerned at the quality of Newsblaze as a source, particularly given it does get usage on the encyclopedia.

*'''Option 1:''' The source is recognized as being [[WP:GREL|generally reliable]].
*'''Option 2:''' There is [[Wikipedia:MREL|no consensus or additional considerations apply]].
*'''Option 3:''' The source is recognized as being [[Wikipedia:GUNREL|generally unreliable]] in most cases, though it can be used under certain circumstances.
*'''Option 4:''' The source is recognized as being not reliable at all and should be [[Wikipedia:Deprecated sources|deprecated]].

- [[User:David Gerard|David Gerard]] ([[User talk:David Gerard|talk]]) 17:05, 4 September 2021 (UTC)}}

=== [[Wikipedia:Universal Code of Conduct/Enforcement draft guidelines review#rfc_780D380|Wikipedia:Universal Code of Conduct/Enforcement draft guidelines review]] expired 2021-09-16 17:01 ===
* Id: 780D380
* User: Xeno (WMF)
* Date: 2021-08-17 16:11:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_policies_and_guidelines|prev|1039258421|POLICY 1039258421}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_policies_and_guidelines|prev|1044706682|POLICY 1044706682}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
The [[m:Special:MyLanguage/Universal Code of Conduct/Drafting committee#Phase 2|Universal Code of Conduct Phase 2 drafting committee]] would like comments about the '''[[m:Special:MyLanguage/Universal Code of Conduct/Enforcement draft guidelines review#Enforcement draft guidelines|enforcement draft guidelines]]''' (also copied below) for the [[m:Special:MyLanguage/Universal Code of Conduct|Universal Code of Conduct (UCoC)]]. This review period is planned for 17 August 2021 through 17 October 2021. Comments are invited [[Wikipedia:Universal Code of Conduct/Enforcement draft guidelines review#Enforcement draft guidelines review|below]] or at [[m:Talk:Universal Code of Conduct/Enforcement draft guidelines review|the draft review talk page on Meta]] in any language, [[m:Special:PrefixIndex/Talk:Universal Code of Conduct/Enforcement draft guidelines review|talk pages of translations]], [[m:Special:MyLanguage/Universal Code of Conduct/Discussions|local discussions]], [[m:Special:MyLanguage/Universal Code of Conduct/2021 consultations/Roundtable discussions|round-table discussions]], [[m:Special:MyLanguage/Universal Code of Conduct/2021 consultations/Roundtable discussions#Conversation hours|conversation hours]], through other forms of outreach, and by email to ucocproject[[File:At sign.svg|16x16px|link=|alt=(_AT_)]]wikimedia.org.

Input from Wikimedia communities has been gathered [[m:Special:MyLanguage/Universal Code of Conduct/Discussions|throughout the UCoC project]]. The collected material was reviewed by a [[m:Special:MyLanguage/Universal Code of Conduct/Drafting committee|drafting committee]] of 11 volunteers and four Wikimedia Foundation staff members. They met [[m:Special:MyLanguage/Universal_Code_of_Conduct/Drafting_committee/Phase_2_meeting_summaries|over several months]] to produce the enforcement draft guidelines for a comprehensive community review. The input collected will be used to further refine the guidelines. [[User:Xeno (WMF)|Xeno (WMF)]] ([[User talk:Xeno (WMF)|talk]]) 16:11, 17 August 2021 (UTC)}}

=== [[Talk:Julian Assange#rfc_99AFAFB|Talk:Julian Assange]] expired 2021-09-17 10:01 ===
* Id: 99AFAFB
* User: Slatersteven
* Date: 2021-08-18 09:57:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Biographies|prev|1039374497|BIO 1039374497}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Politics,_government,_and_law|prev|1039374508|POL 1039374508}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Biographies|prev|1044840407|BIO 1044840407}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Politics,_government,_and_law|prev|1044840415|POL 1044840415}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
Statement:
Should the following text be in the article?

On 26 June 2021, Stundin, an Icelandic newspaper, reported that a key witness in the United States‚Äô case against Assange had admitted to giving false testimony used in the superseding U.S. indictment. The witness, Sigurdur Thordarson, told the paper he fabricated earlier testimony that Assange had instructed him to hack into the computers of members of Iceland's parliament, as well as other allegations. Thordarson said he had been working with the U.S. Department of Justice and FBI in return for a promise the agencies would not share with Icelandic authorities information that could lead to a prosecution of Thordarson. According to the interview, Thordarson continued his criminal activities while working with the FBI with the promise of immunity from prosecution.[462] The Washington Post reported that Thordarson's testimony served as background for what Assange allegedly told Manning. The paper noted that supporters including Edward Snowden have said the admission of fabricated testimony undermines the case against Assange. However, their report states that the interview does not touch on the core allegations against Assange.[463] Private Eye states that the claims from the witness feature extensively in the UK court judgement, and that the U.S. hacking charges rely heavily on the testimony that the witness now admits was fabricated.[464][[User:Slatersteven|Slatersteven]] ([[User talk:Slatersteven|talk]]) 09:57, 18 August 2021 (UTC)}}

=== [[Talk:Abortion law#rfc_06E1344|Talk:Abortion law]] expired 2021-09-20 12:01 ===
* Id: 06E1344
* User: Heitordp
* Date: 2021-09-09 03:16:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Politics,_government,_and_law|prev|1043249534|POL 1043249534}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Politics,_government,_and_law|prev|1045402572|POL 1045402572}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
A law in Texas, effective 1 September 2021, requires abortion providers to try to detect an embryonic or fetal heartbeat, and prohibits them from performing the abortion if the heartbeat is detected, except for medical emergencies. Normally it's possible to detect a heartbeat about 6 weeks after the last menstrual period. Most women tend to find out that they are pregnant after this time, thus missing the legal opportunity to abort, but if they find out earlier they are still allowed. Given these circumstances, how should Texas and the United States be shown in [[abortion law]]? (See the article for the meaning of the colors.)
*'''Option 1''': In the table, mark the last 4 columns of Texas in light red, and the last 4 columns of the United States in yellow, with notes explaining the details. In the map, mark Texas in orange, and the rest of the United States in blue.
*'''Option 2''': In the table, mark the last 4 columns of Texas in light green, and the last 4 columns of the United States also in light green, with notes explaining the details. In the map, mark all of the United States in blue.
Thank you. [[User:Heitordp|Heitordp]] ([[User talk:Heitordp|talk]]) 03:16, 9 September 2021 (UTC)}}

=== [[Talk:Great power#rfc_381AAB9|Talk:Great power]] expired 2021-09-22 19:01 ===
* Id: 381AAB9
* User: 51.7.116.157
* Date: 2021-08-23 18:53:00

** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Politics,_government,_and_law|prev|1045846551|POL 1045846551}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
1. Is Italy a Great Power? If it is not a Great power or only a disputed one, should the article change the "Emerging powers" section to a "Possible Great Powers" section <small>(or a different name)</small>?<br>
2. Should the map showing Great powers be updated to include Italy? Should the map also include disputed & emerging powers discussed in the Article? Should the map be removed entirely?<br>
3. What should be done with the [[Template:List of great powers by date]]? Should it be limited to the end of WWII when all sources agreed on who was a Great power? Should it go until the end of the millennium or the fall of the soviet union? If the template goes beyond WWII, should Italy be included with other Great powers? Should the template be removed entirely?<br>
<br>
Maybe you can see another solution that we have missed.--[[Special:Contributions/51.7.116.157|51.7.116.157]] ([[User talk:51.7.116.157|talk]]) 18:53, 23 August 2021 (UTC)}}

=== [[Talk:Short track speed skating at the 2002 Winter Olympics ‚Äì Men's 1500 metres#rfc_BC3D168|Talk:Short track speed skating at the 2002 Winter Olympics ‚Äì Men's 1500 metres]] expired 2021-09-23 13:01 ===
* Id: BC3D168
* User: 175.124.86.89
* Date: 2021-08-24 12:23:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Society,_sports,_and_culture|prev|1040419539|SOC 1040419539}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Society,_sports,_and_culture|prev|1045999127|SOC 1045999127}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
This discussion will be applied to the following articles:
* [[2002 Winter Olympics]]
* [[Short track speed skating at the 2002 Winter Olympics ‚Äì Men's 1500 metres]]
* [[Kim Dong-sung]]
* [[Apolo Ohno]]
* [[James Hewish]]

{{Reply to|188.65.246.175}} I still believe that [[Kim Dong-sung]] unfairly lost the gold medal thanks to [[James Hewish]]'s misjudgement and [[Apolo Ohno]]'s simulated foul that led to it. But I tried my best at maintaining NPOV while I was revising the paragraphs in question days ago to best describe what actually happened (or what appeared to happen) back in 2002. If you still think my writing was biased, why don't you reword them to adhere to what you think was neutral, instead of reverting them outright?

Also, while I was on it, I replaced some dead and/or questionable Korean language sources with remaining and/or credible ones.

And I moved the detailed writings about the incident from the [[Apolo Ohno]] article to [[Short track speed skating at the 2002 Winter Olympics ‚Äì Men's 1500 metres]] because I think it's better suited in the article about the event, while the article about the American skater can focus on Ohno's feelings and later remarks about the incident. --[[Special:Contributions/175.124.86.89|175.124.86.89]] ([[User talk:175.124.86.89|talk]]) 12:23, 24 August 2021 (UTC)}}

=== [[Talk:Amrullah Saleh#rfc_A11EC1D|Talk:Amrullah Saleh]] expired 2021-09-23 20:01 ===
* Id: A11EC1D
* User: Loesorion
* Date: 2021-08-24 19:34:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Biographies|prev|1040479339|BIO 1040479339}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Biographies|prev|1046068014|BIO 1046068014}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
There is currently a dispute about could Amrullah Saleh become president as successor of former president per Afghan constitution and what sources could be used to prove that. It regards important note that in article should be to described how Amrullah Saleh obtained his highest public function.  What sources for such edit exists and how they could be used?

Could we add in article -
"under Afghanistan constitution article 60 Vice President can become president in case when president is absent as he is direct successor" 

with support of primary and other secondary source regarding constitution 

or simply add he is 

"president per Afghanistan constitution" 

as it is supported by many sources or both as one part is regarding ways of succession and other is actual state. Is constitution reliable as a primary source when used with care and backed by secondary sources that confirm that it is used with care - is it good for editing when it comes to legal matters that should be very strict in this case to describe succession possibility.

I am trying to improve article to add statement that it is possible for vice president of Afghanistan to become president according to constitution including maybe some legal quotes or statement about succession.

Primary source - Afghan constitution - is at my opinion here in this situation best available source in terms of reliability about succession while one secondary source exists that confirms that First Vice President of Afghanistan becomes President under constitution
[[User:Loesorion|Loesorion]] ([[User talk:Loesorion|talk]]) 19:34, 24 August 2021 (UTC)}}

=== [[Talk:The New York Times#rfc_330DD2C|Talk:The New York Times]] expired 2021-09-25 14:01 ===
* Id: 330DD2C
* User: Nesher
* Date: 2021-08-26 13:26:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Media,_the_arts,_and_architecture|prev|1040760489|MEDIA 1040760489}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Media,_the_arts,_and_architecture|prev|1046405438|MEDIA 1046405438}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
Should the following text be added into:

A)The article lede.

B)The article body.

C)Not this text, but something should appear about criticism of the NYT's climate science coverage.

D)This text (and/or theme) should not appear in the article.


{{tq|The ''Times''' editorial board has promoted scientific views of uncertainty with the [[scientific consensus on climate change]],<ref>{{cite journal |last1=Zehr |first1=Stephen C. |doi=10.1088/0963-6625/9/2/301 |title=Public representations of scientific uncertainty about global climate change | journal=[[Public Understanding of Science]] |year=2000 |volume=9 |issue=2 | page = 89|doi-access=free}}</ref> significantly omitted basic climate facts in its articles,<ref>{{cite journal |last1=M Romps |first1=David |last2=P Retzinger|first2=Jean |doi=10.1088/2515-7620/ab37dd |title=Climate news articles lack basic climate science| journal=[[Environmental Research Communications]] |year=2019 |volume=1 |issue=8 |doi-access=free}}</ref> and offered a denial discourse leading to informationally biased coverage of global warming.<ref>{{cite journal |last1=T. Boykoff|first1=Maxwell|last2=M. Boykoff|first2=Jules| doi=10.1016/j.gloenvcha.2003.10.001 |title=Balance as bias: global warming and the US prestige press | journal=[[Global Environmental Change]] |year=2004 |volume=14 |issue=2 | page = 126, 134 |doi-access=free}}</ref>}}


:----[[User:Nesher|Nesher]] ([[User talk:Nesher|talk]]) 13:26, 26 August 2021 (UTC)}}

=== [[Wikipedia:Reliable sources/Noticeboard#rfc_E8764A0|Wikipedia:Reliable sources/Noticeboard]] expired 2021-09-27 06:01 ===
* Id: E8764A0
* User: Szmenderowiecki
* Date: 2021-09-04 19:22:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Biographies|prev|1042677690|BIO 1042677690}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Politics,_government,_and_law|prev|1042677696|POL 1042677696}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Media,_the_arts,_and_architecture|prev|1042980642|MEDIA 1042980642}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Society,_sports,_and_culture|prev|1042980650|SOC 1042980650}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Biographies|prev|1048205473|BIO 1048205473}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Media,_the_arts,_and_architecture|prev|1048205479|MEDIA 1048205479}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Politics,_government,_and_law|prev|1048205493|POL 1048205493}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Society,_sports,_and_culture|prev|1048205495|SOC 1048205495}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
{{not a vote}}

A dispute has been raging in June and July about reliability of some sources in the context of [[Jan ≈ªaryn]], a conservative Polish politician, which spilt into [[WP:NPPSG]], hence the scope of the request. Details will be mentioned in the "Discussion" section on the dispute, so that the RfC question fits in here.

Please evaluate the following resources in the following manner:

*'''Option 1:''' The source is recognized as being [[WP:GREL|generally reliable]].
*'''Option 2:''' There is [[Wikipedia:MREL|no consensus or additional considerations apply]].
*'''Option 3:''' The source is recognized as being [[Wikipedia:GUNREL|generally unreliable]] in most cases, though it can be used under certain circumstances.
*'''Option 4:''' The source is recognized as being not reliable at all and should be [[Wikipedia:Deprecated sources|deprecated]].

Thank you. [[User:Szmenderowiecki|Szmenderowiecki]] ([[User talk:Szmenderowiecki|talk]]) 19:22, 4 September 2021 (UTC)}}

=== [[Wikipedia:Reliable sources/Noticeboard#rfc_11D188C|Wikipedia:Reliable sources/Noticeboard]] expired 2021-09-27 06:01 ===
* Id: 11D188C
* User: TheSandDoctor
* Date: 2021-08-28 05:32:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Media,_the_arts,_and_architecture|prev|1041039253|MEDIA 1041039253}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_policies_and_guidelines|prev|1041039254|POLICY 1041039254}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Media,_the_arts,_and_architecture|prev|1046738164|MEDIA 1046738164}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_policies_and_guidelines|prev|1046738173|POLICY 1046738173}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
Which of the following best describes the [[WP:RS|reliability]] of ''[[Business Insider|Insider]]'' for its original [https://www.insider.com/culture culture reporting]?

'''Note''' this is section specific in efforts to try and find some narrow consensus as all previous discussions focusing on the sites as a whole have ended "no consensus".
*'''Option 1:''' Generally [[WP:RS|reliable]] for factual reporting
*'''Option 2:''' Unclear or additional considerations apply
*'''Option 3:''' Generally [[WP:QUESTIONABLE|unreliable]] for factual reporting
*'''Option 4:''' Publishes false or fabricated information, and should be [[WP:DEPS|deprecated]]
--[[User:TheSandDoctor|<span style="color:#FF9933; font-weight:bold; font-family:monotype;">The</span><span style="color:#009933; font-weight:bold;">SandDoctor</span>]] <sup>[[User talk:TheSandDoctor|<span style="color:#009933;">Talk</span>]]</sup> 05:32, 28 August 2021 (UTC)}}

=== [[Category talk:Sexual misconduct allegations#rfc_9AAACFA|Category talk:Sexual misconduct allegations]] expired 2021-09-28 20:01 ===

* User: Animalparty
* Date: 2021-08-29 19:14:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Biographies|prev|1041308666|BIO 1041308666}}

* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
This category currently includes articles about allegations and controversies such as [[Bill Clinton sexual assault and misconduct allegations]] and [[BBC sexual abuse cases]]. It also includes several biographies that discuss allegations in the article, such as [[Dustin Hoffman]] and [[Corey Feldman]], as well as redirects such as ''[[T.J. Miller sexual misconduct allegations]]'' and ''[[Herman Cain sexual misconduct allegations]]''.  Inclusion of biographies may potentially violate [[WP:BLPCAT]], [[WP:COPDEF]], [[MOS:LABEL]], and *[[WP:OPINIONCAT]]. Should individual biographies of living or dead people be placed in this category? I believe this can be broken down into 3 choices, below. [[User:Animalparty|--Animalparty!]] ([[User talk:Animalparty|talk]]) 19:14, 29 August 2021 (UTC)}}

{{rfcquote|text=
Should the article [[Julian Assange]] include the following information, sourced to ''The Daily Telegraph'', ''The Guardian'', ''The Times'' and ''Yahoo News'':

According to former intelligence officials, following the Vault&nbsp;7 leaks senior officials in the CIA discussed plans to either [[kidnapping|kidnap]] Assange from the embassy or assassinate him, going so far as to request "sketches" or "options" for doing so. No plans were approved, partly because White House lawyers raised concerns about the legality of such an operation. Some officials, interviewed as part of an investigation by ''[[Yahoo News]]'', stated that they were sufficiently concerned about the proposals that they alerted staffers and members of the House and Senate intelligence committees.

=== [[Wikipedia talk:Manual of Style#rfc_3D6BE53|Wikipedia talk:Manual of Style]] expired 2021-10-03 05:01 ===
* Id: 3D6BE53
* User: Herostratus
* Date: 2021-09-03 18:57:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_style_and_naming|prev|1042208850|STYLE 1042208850}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_style_and_naming|prev|1048004415|STYLE 1048004415}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
 Should the MoS give guidance on how to alphabetize foreign-language terms that include letters not in the basic Latin alphabet, such as "√ã" and "√Ö" and so forth? {{br}}

'''1)''' No.{{br}}
'''2)''' Yes, and:
:'''2A)''' Yes, and we should use each language's system (for instance, some languages treat "√ñ" as a distinct letter that comes after "Z"). This is described at the article [[Alphabetical order]].
:'''2B''' Yes, and we should use the French system always (that is, "√î" and "√ñ" etc are treated exactly like "O" and so on).
:'''2C)''' Yes, and we should use Unicode order, as described at [[Wikipedia:Alphabetical order]].
'''3)''' Other [describe]. [[User:Herostratus|Herostratus]] ([[User talk:Herostratus|talk]]) 18:57, 3 September 2021 (UTC)}}

=== [[Wikipedia talk:Manual of Style/Layout#rfc_952205B|Wikipedia talk:Manual of Style/Layout]] expired 2021-10-03 09:01 ===
* Id: 952205B
* User: IceWelder
* Date: 2021-09-03 09:00:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_style_and_naming|prev|1042120915|STYLE 1042120915}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_style_and_naming|prev|1047924057|STYLE 1047924057}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
The [[#Clarification: DISPLAYTITLE|above discussion]] shows that there is some consensus to include the DISPLAYTITLE family of templates‚Äî{{tl|DISPLAYTITLE}}, {{tl|Lowercase title}}, {{tl|Italic title}}, and {{tl|Italic dab}}‚Äîin the "Order of article elements" section of this style guideline. The central argument is completeness: Several editors (including myself) use this guideline to determine where to place various elements, and the lack of a common template type like DISPLAYTITLE is destined to cause inconsistencies. There was no concurrence on ''where'' these elements should be placed within the list of elements. I announced my intent to open an RfC on the matter, which was not met with any opposition, so here we are. [[User:IceWelder|<span style="font-variant: small-caps;">IceWelder</span>]] &#91;[[User talk:IceWelder|<span style="color: #424242;">&#9993;</span>]]&#93; 09:00, 3 September 2021 (UTC)}}

=== [[Wikipedia talk:List of hoaxes on Wikipedia#rfc_E0AE764|Wikipedia talk:List of hoaxes on Wikipedia]] expired 2021-10-07 13:01 ===
* Id: E0AE764
* User: Piotrus
* Date: 2021-09-07 12:39:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/WikiProjects_and_collaborations|prev|1042908745|PROJ 1042908745}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/WikiProjects_and_collaborations|prev|1048692393|PROJ 1048692393}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
This page includes many entries about supposed hoaxes that do not meet the inclusion criteria (quoting from this very article: "For the purpose of this list, a hoax is defined as '''a clear and deliberate attempt to deceptively present false information as fact'''."). And from [[WP:HOAX]] "A hoax is an attempt to trick an audience into believing that something false is real". Also, please note this is not a wiki-jargon issue: from [[Hoax]]: "a falsehood deliberately fabricated to masquerade as the truth", CED [https://dictionary.cambridge.org/dictionary/english/hoax] "a plan to deceive someone". The key issue is that a hoax needs to be '''deliberate''', but we don't have any proof that this is the case for many entries here, most of which are just various errors - but ones that could've been added in good faith. Calling them hoaxes violates [[WP:AGF]] and creates a misleading impression that many errors on Wikipedia are deliberate - a violation of [[Hanlon's razor]], better known as the adage "never attribute to malice that which is adequately explained by stupidity". Please read below for a more detailed analysis. --<sub style="border:1px solid #228B22;padding:1px;">[[User:Piotrus|Piotr Konieczny aka Prokonsul Piotrus]]&#124;[[User talk:Piotrus|<span style="color:#7CFC00;background:#006400;"> reply here</span>]]</sub> 12:39, 7 September 2021 (UTC)}}

=== [[Talk:North Africa#rfc_A9997D8|Talk:North Africa]] expired 2021-10-09 14:01 ===
* Id: A9997D8
* User: Iskandar 323
* Date: 2021-09-09 13:30:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/History_and_geography|prev|1043322181|HIST 1043322181}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/History_and_geography|prev|1049040333|HIST 1049040333}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
There is currently a lack of consensus as to which countries the geographical descriptor of [[North Africa]] should include. This region is messy, with the [[Maghreb]], [[Northwestern Africa]], [[Northeastern Africa]] and [[Middle East]] regional groupings all overlapping. One question that has been discussed extensively on this page in various forms, but lingered unresolved for decades, is whether to include [[Sudan]]. At present, the principle source that includes Sudan in its definition of North Africa is the UN Statistics Division, which uses the UN geo-scheme as its basis. However, the African Union, World Bank, Encylopedia Britannica sources and others exclude it. Sudan is also included as part of [[Northeastern Africa]] and the [[Sahel]] group of countries, and, in some sources, as part of [[East Africa]]. Again, it is principally the UN Statistics Division that excludes it from East Africa. Should Sudan be included in North Africa? Please comment below. [[User:Iskandar 323|Iskandar 323]] ([[User talk:Iskandar 323|talk]]) 13:30, 9 September 2021 (UTC)}}

=== [[Talk:Silicon Valley#rfc_1D8C7E5|Talk:Silicon Valley]] expired 2021-10-09 19:01 ===
* Id: 1D8C7E5
* User: Binksternet
* Date: 2021-09-09 18:43:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Economy,_trade,_and_companies|prev|1043367069|ECON 1043367069}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/History_and_geography|prev|1043367073|HIST 1043367073}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Maths,_science,_and_technology|prev|1043367077|SCI 1043367077}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Politics,_government,_and_law|prev|1043367080|POL 1043367080}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Society,_sports,_and_culture|prev|1043367085|SOC 1043367085}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Economy,_trade,_and_companies|prev|1049083168|ECON 1049083168}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/History_and_geography|prev|1049083171|HIST 1049083171}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Maths,_science,_and_technology|prev|1049083176|SCI 1049083176}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Politics,_government,_and_law|prev|1049083181|POL 1049083181}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Society,_sports,_and_culture|prev|1049083183|SOC 1049083183}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
Three articles exist on Wikipedia with substantial overlap in geography: [[Santa Clara Valley]], [[Santa Clara County, California]], and [[Silicon Valley]].

'''Should the three articles cover three different aspects with minimal overlap?''' If so, the proposed inclusion criteria for the three would be:
*'''[[Santa Clara Valley]]''' would cover geology, biology, climate, early human settlement, early history, etc. The economic history, schools, and structures sections would be moved to the County article.
*'''[[Santa Clara County, California]]''', would cover the normal [[metropolitan area]] concerns such as government, transportation, population, modern history and development, communities, etc. The fauna section here would be moved to the Santa Clara Valley article.
*'''[[Silicon Valley]]''' would cover all aspects of the rise of high tech industry in the region, and related culture. <s>The sections from demographics down to and including media would be moved to the County article, leaving behind a short summary of those aspects relating to high-tech industry and culture.</s> [[User:Binksternet|Binksternet]] ([[User talk:Binksternet|talk]]) 18:43, 9 September 2021 (UTC)}}

=== [[Talk:Nation of Islam#rfc_457863C|Talk:Nation of Islam]] expired 2021-10-14 17:01 ===
* Id: 457863C
* User: Gouncbeatduke
* Date: 2021-10-14 13:01:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_policies_and_guidelines|prev|1049895855|POLICY 1049895855}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_policies_and_guidelines|prev|1049920306|POLICY 1049920306}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
Prior to 2016, Nation of Islam (NoI) was a NPOV article that recognized NoI's hate group status in the opening paragraph. More recently it has morphed into a sales pitch. The two main authorities on hate groups in the United States, the [[Southern Poverty Law Center]] and the [[Anti-Defamation League]] are dismissed as "critics" rather than being recognized as reliable sources as they are in well written hate group articles such as the [[Ku Klux Klan]]. At least one police officer has been murdered since Wikipedia stop recognizing NoI as a hate group and started promoting it via a sales pitch. The NYT reports:

"Noah Green, the knife-wielding man killed after ramming his car into a checkpoint at the U.S. Capitol on Friday, was a troubled former college athlete whose life was disintegrating in the months leading up to a violent outburst that left one officer dead and another injured.

On the football field at Christopher Newport University in Virginia, Noah R. Green was No. 21, a dependable and good-natured, if soft-spoken, presence in the defensive backfield. Off the field, he was focused on Black economic empowerment and planned a career to help close the racial wealth gap.

By late March, after a bruising pandemic year that friends and family said left him isolated and mentally unmoored, Mr. Green‚Äôs life appeared increasingly to revolve around the Nation of Islam and its leader Louis Farrakhan, who has repeatedly promoted anti-Semitism." https://www.nytimes.com/2021/04/05/us/politics/heres-what-we-know-about-the-man-behind-fridays-attack-on-capitol-hill.htm

[[User:Gouncbeatduke|Gouncbeatduke]] ([[User talk:Gouncbeatduke|talk]]) 13:01, 14 October 2021 (UTC)}}

=== [[Talk:Nation of Islam#rfc_84B0FD8|Talk:Nation of Islam]] expired 2021-10-15 17:01 ===
* Id: 84B0FD8
* User: Gouncbeatduke
* Date: 2021-10-15 11:53:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_policies_and_guidelines|prev|1050048506|POLICY 1050048506}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_policies_and_guidelines|prev|1050079572|POLICY 1050079572}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
Prior to 2016, Nation of Islam (NoI) was a NPOV article that recognized NoI's hate group status in the opening paragraph. More recently it has morphed into a sales pitch. The two main authorities on hate groups in the United States, the [[Southern Poverty Law Center]] and the [[Anti-Defamation League]] are dismissed as "critics" rather than being recognized as reliable sources as they are in well written hate group articles such as the [[Ku Klux Klan]]. At least one police officer has been murdered since Wikipedia stop recognizing NoI as a hate group and started promoting it via a sales pitch. The NYT reports:

"Noah Green, the knife-wielding man killed after ramming his car into a checkpoint at the U.S. Capitol on Friday, was a troubled former college athlete whose life was disintegrating in the months leading up to a violent outburst that left one officer dead and another injured.

On the football field at Christopher Newport University in Virginia, Noah R. Green was No. 21, a dependable and good-natured, if soft-spoken, presence in the defensive backfield. Off the field, he was focused on Black economic empowerment and planned a career to help close the racial wealth gap.

By late March, after a bruising pandemic year that friends and family said left him isolated and mentally unmoored, Mr. Green‚Äôs life appeared increasingly to revolve around the Nation of Islam and its leader Louis Farrakhan, who has repeatedly promoted anti-Semitism." https://www.nytimes.com/2021/04/05/us/politics/heres-what-we-know-about-the-man-behind-fridays-attack-on-capitol-hill.htm

Please restore the following sentence to the opening paragraph:

The NOI is tracked as a hate group by the Southern Poverty Law Center. 

[[User:Gouncbeatduke|Gouncbeatduke]] ([[User talk:Gouncbeatduke|talk]]) 11:53, 15 October 2021 (UTC)}}

=== [[Talk:Julian Assange#rfc_F59B4BA|Talk:Julian Assange]] expired 2021-10-17 12:01 ===
* Id: F59B4BA
* User: Slatersteven
* Date: 2021-09-17 11:38:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Biographies|prev|1044854783|BIO 1044854783}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Politics,_government,_and_law|prev|1044854789|POL 1044854789}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Biographies|prev|1050368693|BIO 1050368693}}

* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
Should we say

'''A''' "Assange must have known that Rich could not have been the source of the leak, because he received the mails when Rich was already dead and continued to confer with the Russian hackers to coordinate the release of the material"

'''B'''. "Assange continued to deny Russian involvement even though he had received the emails after Rich's death and was conferring with the Russian hackers to coordinate the release of the material."

'''C'''. "Assange received the emails when Rich was already dead, and continued to confer with the Russian hackers to coordinate the release of the material."

'''D'''. ‚ÄúAssange received the emails when Rich was already dead, and continued to confer with the Guccifer 2 to coordinate the release of the material"

'''E'''. Exclude.

'''F'''. ‚ÄúAssange received the emails when Rich was already dead, and conferred with Guccifer 2.0 (a persona thought to have been created by Russian hackers) in order to coordinate the release of the material."

I'd like to start the [[Wikipedia:Reliable sources/Perennial sources]] discussion for [[Caixin]].

Which of the following best describe the work of Caixin:
*'''Option 1''': Generally reliable for factual reporting;
*'''Option 2''': Unclear or additional considerations apply;
*'''Option 3''': Generally unreliable for factual reporting; or
*'''Option 4''': Publishes false or fabricated information, and should be deprecated.

=== [[Wikipedia:Reliable sources/Noticeboard#rfc_65A8CF1|Wikipedia:Reliable sources/Noticeboard]] expired 2021-10-21 12:01 ===
* Id: 65A8CF1
* Date: 2021-09-21 20:55:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/History_and_geography|prev|1045679791|HIST 1045679791}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/History_and_geography|prev|1051148545|HIST 1051148545}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
Which of the following best describes the [[WP:RS|reliability]] of the US [[Geographic Names Information System]] (GNIS) database?

*'''Option 1:''' The source is recognized as being [[WP:GREL|generally reliable]].
*'''Option 2:''' There is [[Wikipedia:MREL|no consensus or additional considerations apply]].
*'''Option 3:''' The source is recognized as being [[Wikipedia:GUNREL|generally unreliable]] in most cases, though it can be used under certain circumstances.
*'''Option 4:''' The source is recognized as being not reliable at all and should be [[Wikipedia:Deprecated sources|deprecated]].
*'''Option 5:''' The source is:
**'''Generally reliable''' for Place Names and Locations/Coordinates
**'''Generally unreliable''' for Feature Classes, particularly "Populated place"
**Does not satisfy the "Legal recognition" requirement of [[WP:GEOLAND]].

‚Äì[[User:Dlthewave|dlthewave]] [[User_talk:Dlthewave|‚òé]] 20:55, 21 September 2021 (UTC)}}

* User: Munci

** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Biographies|prev|1051030967|BIO 1051030967}}

* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
Eric Zemmour has been involved with several trials, generally for contrversial statements he has made, often for hate speech. Some of these he has lost, others he has won and others are still underway. As I have mentioned here [https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Talk:%C3%89ric_Zemmour&diff=prev&oldid=1050712583] [https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Talk%3A%C3%89ric_Zemmour&type=revision&diff=1049539640&oldid=1049523020] [https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Talk:%C3%89ric_Zemmour&diff=next&oldid=1049564037] and edited here [https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=%C3%89ric_Zemmour&diff=prev&oldid=1049026929], I consider the section on his trials, and the formatting thereof, unbalanced in favour of Zemmour, as it puts subsections for the trials he won, but not for those he lost or for those still underway. [[User:Munci|Munci]] ([[User talk:Munci|talk]]) 06:08, 21 October 2021 (UTC)}}
